questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office for her first prenatal visit.  The patient has been married for 8 years and has tried to conceive for the past 3 years.  For the past few weeks, she has experienced morning sickness and has had abdominal distension and breast fullness.  Her last menstrual period was 2 months ago, and she reports a positive home pregnancy test 2 weeks ago.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions or prior surgeries.  Blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min.  BMI is 24 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows a soft, nontender, tympanic abdomen with no masses.  Bedside ultrasound examination reveals a thin endometrial stripe.  Two office urine pregnancy tests are negative.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient most likely has pseudocyesis, a persistent nondelusional belief of being pregnant in a nonpregnant patient.  Patients commonly experience symptoms of early pregnancy such as amenorrhea, morning sickness, and abdominal distension, but evaluation excludes pregnancy (eg, negative results on office urine pregnancy tests, thin endometrial stripe on ultrasound).

Pseudocyesis can occur when psychological pressures (eg, difficulty conceiving, as in this patient), social pressures, and the somatization of stress affect the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, or when bodily changes (eg, weight gain, amenorrhea) are misinterpreted by the patient.  The end result is a deeply held, nondelusional belief of being pregnant that may be strong enough to cause a patient to misread a negative home pregnancy test result as positive.  Because pseudocyesis is a form of somatization, management requires psychiatric evaluation and treatment.

(Choice A)  Despite the patient's report of a positive home pregnancy test, the 2 negative office urine pregnancy tests and a thin endometrial stripe seen on ultrasound examination exclude the possibility of an early intrauterine pregnancy.

(Choice B)  An ectopic pregnancy can present with a positive home pregnancy test and an empty uterine cavity (ie, thin endometrial stripe on ultrasound).  However, patients typically have an adnexal mass and a positive pregnancy test in the office.

(Choice C)  A hydatidiform mole can cause a markedly elevated β-hCG level and abdominal distension (ie, uterine size greater than dates).  However, ultrasound examination typically reveals an intrauterine, heterogeneous cystic mass consistent with excessive trophoblastic tissue.

(Choice D)  Following resolution of a complete spontaneous abortion (SAB), office testing (eg, urine pregnancy test, ultrasound examination) may be negative for pregnancy.  In contrast, patients with a missed SAB typically have a positive pregnancy test and an ultrasound revealing a nonviable intrauterine gestation.  In addition, those with missed SABs usually stop having pregnancy symptoms (eg, morning sickness), unlike this patient.

(Choice E)  Premenstrual syndrome (PMS) is associated with regular ovulatory menstrual cycles rather than amenorrhea.  PMS can present with bloating, breast tenderness, and affective symptoms (eg, labile mood) but is not associated with the belief of being pregnant.

Educational objective:
Pseudocyesis is a persistent, nondelusional belief of being pregnant in a nonpregnant patient.  A patient with pseudocyesis can have symptoms of early pregnancy (eg, morning sickness, abdominal distension), but pregnancy testing is negative and ultrasound examination reveals an empty uterus (eg, thin endometrial stripe).

questionList.questionText: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to a recent change in behavior.  The patient was previously polite and soft-spoken, but he has become intermittently irritable, impatient, and rude over the past few weeks.  His parents initially dismissed his new behavior as a "phase"; however, they grew more concerned last night when they discovered that he had stolen money from their wallets and later found him pacing in his room at 4:00 AM.  When questioned by his father about his strange behavior, the patient said, "I have to be careful because I'm being followed by CIA agents."  He has no medical conditions.  His father has chronic pain and insomnia, for which he takes oxycodone and diphenhydramine.  Temperature is 36.6 C (97.9 F), blood pressure is 164/98 mm Hg, pulse is 124/min, and respirations are 18/min.  On physical examination, the patient appears fearful.  He is sweating profusely and his pupils are dilated.  He is observed in the emergency department for several hours, his condition improves, and he is discharged to the care of his parents.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's episodic agitation, insomnia, psychosis (eg, delusions about the CIA), change in behavior (eg, stealing money), and signs of sympathetic hyperactivity (eg, mydriasis, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis) with subsequent return to baseline functioning following an observed period of abstinence are consistent with amphetamine intoxication.  Potential serious complications of amphetamine intoxication include cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, hyperthermia, and intracerebral hemorrhage.

The diagnosis of amphetamine intoxication is clinical.  A positive toxicology screen can be supportive.  However, the decongestant pseudoephedrine and the antidepressants bupropion and selegiline can cause false positives for amphetamines on urine toxicology testing.  Amphetamines include a range of substances, from those prescribed for the treatment of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorders to the newer synthetic cathinones (ie, bath salts), which are not detectable on routine toxicology screens.

(Choice B)  Some symptoms of anticholinergic poisoning (eg, mydriasis, hyperthermia, tachycardia) can occur due to amphetamine intoxication.  Anticholinergic poisoning is differentiated by the presence of dry skin and mucous membranes, motor symptoms (eg, myoclonic jerks, tremors), and other classic anticholinergic manifestations such as ileus and urinary retention.  Delirium is more likely than isolated psychotic symptoms.

(Choice C)  A manic episode of bipolar disorder is characterized by at least a week of elevated/irritable mood, increased energy, decreased need for sleep, and pressured speech; it may also include psychotic features.  Stimulant intoxication can mimic mania and should be ruled out before concluding that a patient is having a manic episode.  A manic episode would not subside quickly without any pharmacologic intervention.

(Choice D)  Diagnosis of primary psychotic disorders requires ruling out substance-induced causes.  Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by acute onset of one or more psychotic symptoms lasting ≥1 day but <1 month, with eventual complete resolution.  Although this patient has psychotic features, his pupillary dilation, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and elevated blood pressure combined with resolution of signs/symptoms during observation support a diagnosis of substance-induced psychosis.

(Choice E)  Delusional disorder can only be diagnosed if a delusion has been present for ≥1 month and does not result from intoxication, as in this patient.

(Choice F)  Opioid (eg, oxycodone) withdrawal symptoms include muscle spasms, joint pain, nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and sweating.  Irritability, hypertension, and mydriasis may occur.  However, delusions are unlikely, and symptoms of opioid withdrawal often last 3-5 days.

Educational objective:
Amphetamine intoxication can present with psychiatric symptoms, including irritability, agitation, and psychosis.  Common physical signs include tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis.

questionList.questionText: A 52-year-old man comes to the office for follow-up for chronic back pain.  Since starting scheduled-dose hydrocodone-acetaminophen 3 months ago, his pain has not interfered with his work.  The patient also takes naproxen as needed and attends tai chi classes twice a week.  He has no other medical conditions and takes no other medications.  The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs.  A review of the state prescription drug monitoring database shows 60 tablets of hydrocodone-acetaminophen refilled every 30 days and no irregularities.  The patient has 3 days of medications left and requests a refill.  A urine drug screen is positive for opiates and phencyclidine (PCP).  After reviewing the results with the patient, he insists that he uses no recreational drugs, including PCP.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
questionList.explanationText:
Urine drug screening (UDS) is done routinely in long-term management of patients taking controlled substances (eg, opioids).  UDS detects concurrent recreational drug use, verifies adherence to treatment (ie, test is positive for the prescribed drug), and identifies possible medication diversion (ie, test is negative despite reported adherence).

However, an in-office UDS can give erroneous results because the immunoassay may cross-react with medications in other classes (ie, false-positives) or may not detect all the drugs (or excreted metabolites) within a class (ie, false-negatives).  For example, common over-the-counter medications (eg, dextromethorphan, diphenhydramine, ibuprofen), which patients often forget to disclose, can cause false-positive results for PCP.  Therefore, confirmatory testing (eg, gas chromatography with mass spectroscopy) should be obtained to verify unexpected results before assuming recreational drug use or addiction that warrants treatment (Choice E).

If recreational drug use is verified, further discussions should address the need for substance use counseling and rehabilitation.  The patient's care plan may need to be changed (eg, tapering off the controlled substance prescription) to comply with state-specific rules and avoid possible dangerous drug interactions (Choices B and C).

(Choice A)  Repeat UDS should be obtained given the possibility of a false-positive, particularly given the lack of irregularities in the prescription drug monitoring program database.  In addition, even if recreational drug use is confirmed, physicians are legally prohibited from reporting it to authorities barring exceptional cases (eg, criminal investigations).

Educational objective:
Urine drug screening can be used in patients on long-term opioid therapy to detect recreational drug use, verify adherence to treatment, and identify possible medication diversion.  However, false-positive and false-negative results can occur; unexpected results require confirmatory testing.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Prescription drug misuse

answerChoiceList.choice: "Because PCP is an illegal drug, I have to report the test result to the appropriate authorities."
"I can't refill your opioid prescription, but if you develop withdrawal symptoms, we can discuss ways to manage that."
"I can prescribe only a limited amount of opioid medication to help you taper off."
"I need to obtain an additional urine study today and will call you to discuss the results."
"It's okay to be honest with me about drug use; I'll refer you to an addiction specialist for treatment."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Urine drug tests: ordering and interpreting results.

questionList.questionText: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to severe nausea and vomiting a day after receiving chemotherapy for oropharyngeal cancer.  He has no other acute symptoms and is otherwise tolerating his treatments.  The patient has a history of bipolar disorder that has been stable, as well as a remote history of alcohol abuse.  Medications include lithium and lamotrigine.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 140/86 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 16/min.  Physical examination shows mild erythema at the excision site of the primary lesion on the base of the tongue but is otherwise normal.  Laboratory results indicate mild dehydration, lithium level of 0.6 mEq/L (normal: 0.6-1.2 mEq/L), and blood alcohol level of 0.  The patient is treated with intravenous normal saline and multiple doses of an antiemetic to stop his vomiting.  Several hours later, he has sudden neck pain, his neck muscles are stiff, and he has difficulty speaking.  Which of the following medications best explains this patient's sudden symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is experiencing an acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) that can occur with dopamine antagonists, including antiemetics such as metoclopramide and prochlorperazine, as well as most antipsychotics.  Other EPS types include parkinsonism and akathisia, both of which can occur after use of a dopamine antagonist such as metoclopramide.

Acute dystonias can develop within hours to days of initiation of a dopamine antagonist.  They are characterized by muscle spasms or stiffness in the head and neck, tongue protrusions, torticollis, and oculogyric crisis (ie, forced, sustained elevation of the eyes in an upward position).  Laryngeal dystonias can be life-threatening as they may obstruct the airway.  Treatment for a dystonic reaction involves discontinuation of the medication and administration of anticholinergic medications (eg, benztropine) or diphenhydramine, and airway protection if necessary.

(Choices A, B, and F)  Aprepitant, hydroxyzine, and ondansetron also have antiemetic effects, but they are not dopamine antagonists and do not cause an EPS.  Aprepitant is a substance P NK1 receptor antagonist.  Hydroxyzine is an antihistamine.  Ondansetron is a serotonin 5-HT3 antagonist.

(Choices C and D)  Lamotrigine (an anticonvulsant) and lithium are used in the treatment of bipolar disorder.  Neither is typically associated with an EPS.  Lamotrigine is associated with Stevens-Johnson syndrome.  Lithium toxicity may cause severe vomiting, but this patient's lithium level is low.

Educational objective:
The antiemetics metoclopramide and prochlorperazine are dopamine antagonists, which, along with most antipsychotics, can cause extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonias, akathisia, and parkinsonism.

questionList.questionText: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife for "unusual behavior."  She says that since last night, the patient has been afraid to go into their bedroom because he sees "evil children" there.  He spent most of the night pacing back and forth in the living room and got minimal sleep.  Five days ago, when the patient had an asthma exacerbation, his primary care physician added a new oral medication to his regimen.  Medical history also includes hypertension and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.  The patient does not drink alcohol but has used marijuana as recently as last week.  Vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits.  The patient is alert and aware of his surroundings.  He reports hearing children laughing at him and frequently covers his ears with his hands.  The patient has no suicidal ideation.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient exhibits the acute onset of psychosis (hallucinations) that is temporally associated with the introduction of a new medication, most likely high-dose glucocorticoid for his asthma exacerbation.  His psychosis does not appear to be associated with delirium (he is alert and oriented) or any other psychiatric or medical illness.

High-dose glucocorticoids, often given for allergic, inflammatory, or autoimmune conditions, may cause glucocorticoid-induced psychosis, an example of medication-induced psychotic disorder.  Psychotic symptoms typically occur during the first week of glucocorticoid treatment but can occur at any time.  Glucocorticoids can also cause manic or depressive symptoms.

(Choice A)  Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms lasting ≥1 day but <1 month.  This diagnosis is excluded if the symptoms are better explained by the effects of a medication or medical illness.

(Choice B)  Cannabis (marijuana) use may cause euphoria, perceptual changes, increased appetite, red eyes, slowed reflexes, dizziness, and impaired coordination.  Paranoia may occur during acute use but is unlikely to be persistent.

(Choice C)  The core feature of delirium is fluctuating cognitive impairment, characterized by poor attention and disorientation; psychotic features may be present secondarily.  This patient is alert and oriented, making delirium less likely.

(Choice E)  This diagnosis would be appropriate if the patient's history, examination, or laboratory results suggested that psychosis was a direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition (eg, CNS tumor causing psychosis).

Educational objective:
Medication-induced psychotic disorder is characterized by the acute onset of delusions and/or hallucinations that are temporally associated with the use of a new medication.  Glucocorticoids, particularly at high doses, are often implicated in new-onset psychotic symptoms in patients who may have no current underlying psychiatric illness.

questionList.title: Substance-induced psychotic disorder

questionList.questionText: Two days after undergoing a laparoscopic partial colectomy to resect a large adenoma, a 45-year-old woman becomes acutely agitated.  She has been anxious and uncooperative since the surgery, but, today, she is repeatedly getting out of bed, shouting "Get your hands off me!  God is watching!" when the nurses try to redirect her.  The patient was given a preoperative dose of intravenous cefoxitin and is receiving IV ketorolac and acetaminophen as needed for pain.  Medical history includes polysubstance use and schizoaffective disorder.  Chart review shows that she has been prescribed sertraline and a long-acting injection of aripiprazole, but she is unable to provide information about when she had her last dose of either.  Temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 18/min.  The patient is diaphoretic and oriented only to person.  Physical examination shows well-healing incision sites with no erythema; the remainder of the examination is limited due to agitation.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Alcohol withdrawal syndrome

Manifestations

Symptoms/signs

Onset since last drink (hr)

Mild withdrawal

Anxiety, insomnia, tremors, diaphoresis, palpitations, gastrointestinal upset, intact orientation

6-24

Seizures

Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic

12-48

Alcoholic hallucinosis

Visual, auditory, or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs

12-48

Delirium tremens

Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, hallucinations

48-96

This patient's delayed onset (>48 hr following hospital admission) of severe delirium, elevated vital signs (eg, hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia), and diaphoresis in the setting of known polysubstance use is consistent with a diagnosis of delirium tremens (DT).  DT is a late complication of alcohol withdrawal that may affect up to 5% of patients who experience an initial mild withdrawal syndrome.  DT does not present before 48 hours after the last drink, and symptoms may take as long as 96 hours to be seen.  After onset, symptoms may persist for up to 5 days and are associated with a mortality rate of up to 5%.

Treatment of DT is similar to that for milder forms of alcohol withdrawal:  Benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam, diazepam) are the pharmacologic treatment of choice.  However, DT is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal and usually requires management in an intensive care unit.

(Choice A)  Patients having an acute psychotic episode may experience bizarre delusions or hallucinations, but fever, tachycardia, hypertension, and diaphoresis suggest DT rather than a psychiatric disorder.

(Choice C)  Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome can occur when antidepressants are stopped abruptly or tapered too quickly.  Symptoms are typically mild and include nausea, fatigue, headache, and dizziness.  Agitation and diaphoresis are possible, but fever and abnormal vital signs would not be expected.

(Choice D)  Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by muscle rigidity, rhabdomyolysis, hyperthermia, and tachycardia immediately following the administration of a volatile inhaled anesthetic (eg, halothane, sevoflurane) in genetically susceptible individuals.

(Choice E)  Opioid withdrawal may present with agitation, diaphoresis, hypertension (usually mild), and tachycardia.  However, gastrointestinal upset (eg, cramping, diarrhea), flu-like symptoms (eg, piloerection, rhinorrhea, myalgia), and yawning are also typically present.  Delirium and fever would not be expected.

(Choice F)  Postoperative encephalopathy is most commonly associated with cardiac surgery and presents with delirium and/or seizures in the immediate postoperative period.  The delayed onset of this patient's symptoms, her history of polysubstance use, and the presence of abnormal vital signs make DT more likely.

Educational objective:
Delirium tremens is a late manifestation of alcohol withdrawal characterized by delirium, hyperthermia, hypertension, and tachycardia 48-96 hours after the last drink.  It requires aggressive management with benzodiazepines, usually in the intensive care unit.

questionList.questionText: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for behavioral concerns and poor school performance.  They think that the patient is being "lazy and difficult" because he refuses to follow directions.  Teachers note that he has a hard time focusing and is "constantly fidgeting" in his seat.  The patient is in the third grade, but his math and reading skills are at a first-grade level.  He has difficulty making friends and frequently gets into fights with his peers.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions except for poor weight gain.  Weight and height are at the 10th percentile; head circumference is <3rd percentile for his age.  Physical examination reveals a cheerful patient with epicanthal folds and an upturned nose.  The upper lip is thin, and the distance between the medial and lateral canthi of the eyes appears short.  Cardiopulmonary and neurologic examinations are normal.  Which of the following additional pieces of history would most likely account for this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of fetal alcohol syndrome

Facial
dysmorphisms

  • Smooth philtrum
  • Thin vermillion border
  • Small palpebral fissures

Growth

  • Height, weight & head circumference <10th percentile

Neurobehavioral

  • Developmental delay
  • Cognitive impairment
  • Behavioral issues (eg, ADHD, poor social skills)
  • Seizures

ADHD = attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

This patient with behavioral concerns and learning difficulties also has poor growth, microcephaly, and facial dysmorphisms.  These findings are concerning for fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) due to in utero alcohol exposure; a thorough history of prenatal substance use should be obtained.

Alcohol is a teratogen that crosses the placenta to the fetus and can result in a range of neurobehavioral abnormalities, including reduced brain growth, particularly in the frontal lobe.  FAS can manifest with symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), as seen in this patient with difficulty focusing and constant fidgeting.  Cognitive impairment (eg, learning disabilities) and poor social skills are common due to deleterious effects on the prefrontal cortex.

In addition to neurobehavioral abnormalities, FAS is associated with growth restriction (height and weight typically <10th percentile) and facial dysmorphisms.  A smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, and small palpebral fissures (distance between medial and lateral canthi) are characteristic of FAS, but other findings may include epicanthal folds and an upturned nose, as seen in this patient, as well as midface hypoplasia.

(Choice A)  Lead poisoning can present with cognitive impairment and behavioral issues but would not explain this patient's dysmorphic facial features.

(Choice B)  Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability, and behavioral issues (eg, ADHD, autism) are commonly associated with it.  However, stereotypical physical features include a long, narrow face and prominent ears, chin, and forehead.  In addition, a relatively large head size, not microcephaly, would be expected.

(Choice C)  Late congenital syphilis due to infection acquired in utero can cause intellectual disability, but characteristic craniofacial findings include frontal bossing, saddle nose, and Hutchinson teeth, not a thin upper lip or short palpebral fissures.

(Choice D)  International travel during pregnancy may increase the risk for intrauterine exposure to Zika virus, which can cause microcephaly, growth restriction, and cognitive deficits.  However, neurologic manifestations often develop in infancy and include hypertonia, hyperreflexia, and spasticity, findings not seen in this patient.  In addition, a thin upper lip and short palpebral fissures are not associated with congenital Zika infection.

Educational objective:
Fetal alcohol syndrome should be considered in a patient with neurobehavioral issues (eg, cognitive impairment, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, poor social skills), growth restriction, and facial dysmorphisms.  Characteristic findings include a smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, and short palpebral fissures.

questionList.title: Fetal alcohol syndrome

answerChoiceList.choice: In utero exposure to a sexually transmitted disease

questionList.questionText: A 46-year-old woman with alcohol use disorder comes to the office for follow-up.  The patient has a prolonged history of heavy alcohol use and was hospitalized 6 months ago due to alcohol-induced pancreatitis.  She stopped drinking after the hospitalization but restarted following a fight with her husband a month ago.  Her daughters convinced her to stop again, and she has had no drinks for the past 2 weeks.  The patient reports no anxiety or shakiness but has had occasional cravings and is afraid that she may relapse again.  She has no other medical conditions, takes no medications, and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs.  Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination shows no abnormalities.  In addition to psychosocial interventions, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Alcohol use disorder

Clinical features

  • Drinking in larger amounts, inability to cut down, cravings
  • Drinking in hazardous situations, failure to fulfill role obligations, continued drinking despite health/psychological/interpersonal problems
  • Evidence of tolerance & withdrawal

Psychosocial treatment

  • Motivational interviewing
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Residential treatment/rehabilitation
  • Mutual help groups (eg, Alcoholics Anonymous)

Pharmacotherapy

  • Naltrexone
  • Acamprosate (preferred in patients with liver disease or opioid use)
  • Disulfiram is second-line therapy in highly motivated patients

Patients with moderate to severe alcohol use disorder (AUD) should be offered pharmacotherapy in addition to psychosocial interventions.  Medications that target the reinforcing effects of alcohol by modulating opioid and glutamate function have been shown to decrease cravings, reduce alcohol consumption, and help maintain abstinence.

  • Acamprosate, a glutamate modulator at metabotropic glutamate receptor 5, is a first-line treatment that would help reduce this patient's risk of relapse.  It is excreted mostly unchanged by the kidneys, and can be used safely in patients with liver disease, but requires dosage adjustment in patients with renal failure.

  • Naltrexone, a mu-opioid receptor antagonist, is another first-line option for AUD.  However, it has been associated with hepatotoxicity and is contraindicated in patients with liver disease and those taking prescribed opioid medication.

(Choice B)  Benzodiazepines (eg, chlordiazepoxide) are indicated for the treatment of moderate to severe alcohol withdrawal.  They do not treat AUD and have a high risk of abuse.  This patient has been abstinent for 2 weeks and shows no signs of withdrawal.

(Choice C)  Disulfiram, an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor, is an aversive agent that causes an unpleasant physiologic reaction (eg, tachycardia, flushed skin, headache, nausea, vomiting) when alcohol is consumed.  Candidates for disulfiram must be highly motivated or supervised because they may skip a dose to avoid the averse reaction when alcohol is desired.  It is considered a second-line agent for use when naltrexone and acamprosate are either ineffective or contraindicated.

(Choice D)  Fomepizole is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used as an antidote to treat methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning.

(Choice E)  Naloxone is a short-acting opioid antagonist used to treat acute opioid intoxication.

Educational objective:
A combination of psychosocial interventions and pharmacotherapy is indicated for patients with moderate to severe alcohol use disorder.  Acamprosate and naltrexone are first-line medication options.

questionList.questionText: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to learning difficulties at school.  The patient was adopted from an overseas orphanage at age 5 and stayed home until beginning kindergarten 6 months ago.  His birth and developmental history are unknown.  Since beginning school, he has struggled to keep up with reading and writing.  Educational testing was completed and showed an intelligence quotient (IQ) of 68.  Audiology revealed a mild conductive hearing loss in his right ear.  The patient's mother says, "He is a really happy kid and enjoys playing with his older siblings.  I know he doesn't talk as much as other kids his age, but I thought that would improve with time."  Vital signs are within normal limits; weight and height curves are at the 70th and 10th percentiles, respectively.  The patient is sitting on the floor playing with a range of toys.  Physical examination is significant for a flat nasal bridge and a grade 3 holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border.  He makes eye contact, has a friendly demeanor, and responds to questions with 3- to 4-word phrases.  Which of the following tests is most likely to reveal the diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Common causes of intellectual disability

Syndrome

Dysmorphic features

Comorbid conditions

Down syndrome

  • Upslanting palpebral fissures
  • Flat nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal folds
  • Single palmar crease
  • Heart disease (eg, AV canal defect)
  • Short stature, obesity
  • Hearing loss

Fragile X syndrome

  • Long face with prominent chin & forehead
  • Large, protruding ears
  • Macroorchidism
  • Macrocephaly
  • Self-injurious behavior (eg, hand biting)
  • Anxiety, autistic behaviors
  • Tall stature

Fetal alcohol syndrome

  • Smooth philtrum
  • Thin vermillion border
  • Small palpebral fissures
  • Seizures
  • Growth restriction

AV = atrioventricular.

This patient with learning difficulties and a low intelligence quotient (IQ) has intellectual disability.  In the setting of dysmorphic features or a family history of intellectual disability, a genetic cause should be suspected.

In this case, the most likely cause is Down syndrome, the most common chromosomal abnormality associated with intellectual disability.  Congenital heart defects (eg, atrioventricular defect, ventricular septal defect [VSD]) occur in 50% of patients; the holosystolic murmur in this case is consistent with a VSD.  Hearing impairment due to congenital hearing loss or frequent otitis media is also common.  Patients often have a friendly demeanor and poor vertical growth, as seen here.

The diagnosis is frequently established based on prenatal testing or characteristic dysmorphic features at birth (eg, flat nasal bridge).  However, in a patient with mosaicism (extra copy of chromosome 21 in some cells), such dysmorphic features may be less prominent and diagnosis may be delayed.  A karyotype should be performed; identification of trisomy 21 is diagnostic.

(Choice A)  FMR1 DNA analysis detects the gene mutation responsible for Fragile X syndrome (FXS).  Boys with FXS typically have tall stature and a long, narrow face, not a flat nasal bridge.  FXS also would not explain this patient's hearing loss or murmur.

(Choice C)  Rett syndrome, typically due to MECP2 mutations, is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by loss of speech after a period of normal development, as well as stereotypical hand movements and gait abnormalities.  It occurs almost exclusively in girls.

(Choice D)  MRI of the head is indicated for focal neurologic deficits, seizures, or progressive degenerative neurologic symptoms.  MRI findings in patients with mild intellectual disability are often normal or nonspecific and would not diagnose DS.

(Choice E)  Serum hexosaminidase A levels should be measured for suspected Tay-Sachs disease, a lysosomal storage disease that usually presents in infancy with severe neurodegeneration (eg, progressive weakness, loss of motor skills) and death by age 2-5.

(Choice F)  Phenylketonuria, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, causes intellectual disability; however, other characteristic features (eg, musty odor, seizure, hypopigmented skin) also would be expected.  In addition, it is not associated with heart disease or hearing loss.

Educational objective:
Down syndrome should be suspected in a child with intellectual disability and characteristic dysmorphic features, cardiac defects, and hearing loss.  Trisomy 21 on karyotype is diagnostic.

questionList.questionText: A 2-day-old term neonate is evaluated for difficulty feeding in the newborn nursery.  The patient is irritable, is not sleeping well, and has had several episodes of vomiting and loose stools for the past day.  Review of maternal history shows that the mother had poor prenatal care and the pregnancy was complicated by fetal growth restriction.  On examination, the patient is diaphoretic with a high-pitched cry and a mild tremor.  The newborn is noted to have occasional sneezing and is mildly tachypneic.  No dysmorphic features are noted, and the remainder of the examination is unremarkable.  Complete blood count, thyroid screening, serum glucose, and calcium levels are within normal limits.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Neonatal abstinence syndrome

Pathophysiology

  • In utero exposure to maternal substances (primarily opioids)

Clinical
manifestations

  • CNS: irritability, hypertonia, tremor, shortened sleep-wake cycles, uncoordinated swallowing
  • Autonomic nervous system: diaphoresis, sneezing, yawning
  • Gastrointestinal: feeding difficulty, vomiting, diarrhea

Diagnosis

  • Primarily clinical
  • Confirm: umbilical cord blood, urine, or meconium drug testing

Treatment

  • Mild withdrawal: nonpharmacologic
    • Minimize environmental stimuli, swaddling, frequent small feeds
  • Moderate to severe withdrawal: pharmacologic
    • Morphine, methadone

This 2-day-old patient with irritability, diaphoresis, and poor feeding most likely has neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS), also known as neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome.

During pregnancy, maternal opioids (eg, methadone, buprenorphine, heroin) cross the placenta and act on the fetus; chronic intrauterine exposure can cause fetal growth restriction, although other factors (eg, polysubstance use, nutrition) may play a role.  After delivery, the abrupt cessation of chronic opioid exposure causes withdrawal.  NAS typically presents within 48 hours of birth for patients exposed to short-acting opioids (eg, heroin) and within 48-72 hours for those exposed to long-acting opioids (eg, methadone).  Clinical manifestations of withdrawal include the following:

  • CNS:  Short sleep-wake cycles, irritability, hypertonicity, tremors, jitteriness
  • Autonomic nervous system (ANS):  Sweating, sneezing, nasal stuffiness, yawning
  • Gastrointestinal (GI) system:  Poor feeding, vomiting, loose stools

Neonates with mild symptoms require only supportive care (swaddling; small, frequent feeds; low-stimulation environment) while their symptoms self-resolve.  Patients with moderate to severe symptoms, such as this newborn, require opioid replacement (eg, methadone, morphine) to manage their symptoms and allow them to feed and gain weight.

(Choice A)  Patients with apnea of prematurity are treated with caffeine.  Although this condition may cause tachypnea and subsequent difficulty feeding, it is unlikely the diagnosis because of this patient's GI and ANS symptoms.

(Choice B)  In infants, famotidine is used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can present with feeding difficulties and vomiting.  GERD would not cause this patient's CNS and ANS symptoms.

(Choice D)  Congenital syphilis can cause fetal growth restriction and nasal discharge; however, patients are asymptomatic at birth and develop symptoms at age 1-2 weeks.  Congenital syphilis is treated with penicillin, but this patient's symptom timeline makes this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice E)  Propranolol is used in the treatment of neonatal Graves disease, which results from the placental transfer of maternal thyroid-stimulating antibodies.  Neonatal Graves disease has a similar presentation to that of NAS (eg, fetal growth restriction, irritability, increased bowel movements); however, this patient's normal thyroid function tests make this diagnosis less likely.

Educational objective:
Neonatal abstinence syndrome is caused by neonatal withdrawal from maternal opioids in the first few days of life.  It is characterized by irritability, a high-pitched cry, poor sleep, tremors, sneezing, tachypnea, poor feeding, vomiting, and diarrhea.  Newborns with moderate to severe symptoms are treated with methadone or morphine.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old woman is called to the office for a random pill count and urine drug screen as a part of chronic pain management with hydrocodone/acetaminophen.  The patient has chronic back pain due to a ski accident 5 months ago.  She is prescribed 1 tablet of hydrocodone/acetaminophen in the morning and 1 tablet in the evening and reported adequate control of her pain at her last follow-up 3 weeks ago.  A query of the prescription drug monitoring database shows she consistently filled 60 tablets of hydrocodone/acetaminophen every 30 days; the prescription was last filled 15 days ago.  Today, a pill count reveals the patient has 10 tablets of hydrocodone/acetaminophen remaining.  Urine drug test confirms the absence of opioids and other tested drugs.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Random pill counts and urine drug screenings are commonly used in chronic opioid therapy to identify opioid misuse.  This patient's urine drug test is negative for opioids despite reported adherence and on-time refills.  Furthermore, her opioid consumption occurred at a higher rate than expected, as evidenced by the fewer-than-expected pill count (would expect 30 tablets to be remaining at 15 days based on her prescription).

These findings raise suspicion for opioid misuse, including opioid diversion (eg, sharing or selling a medication).  Opioid diversion contributes to the public health threat of the opioid epidemic: opioid overdose frequently occurs in individuals who are not prescribed the medication but obtained it from others.  In this patient with a remote injury, well controlled pain despite no opioid use (ie, negative urine drug test result), and a high suspicion for opioid diversion, future prescriptions should be suspended.

(Choice A)  Frequent follow-up visits are recommended during opioid dose titrations to monitor response and adverse effects.  Patients with a history of substance use disorder who are on chronic opioid therapy also should be seen more frequently.  This patient is not taking her prescribed opioids, other controlled substances, or recreational drugs.

(Choice B)  Naloxone should be offered to any patient on chronic opioid therapy to prevent fatal overdose.  This patient is prescribed opioids but not taking them (given the negative urine drug screen result).

(Choice C)  A medication-assisted treatment program (eg, buprenorphine, methadone) is recommended for those with opioid use disorder but is not helpful for diversion.

(Choice E)  Fentanyl transdermal patch is preferred over oral opioids when oral intake is difficult (eg, dysphagia), gastrointestinal absorption is compromised, opioid-related constipation is problematic, or renal function is impaired; these indications are not present in this patient.

Educational objective:
Opioid diversion (ie, sharing or selling of medication) should be suspected when a urine drug test confirms absence of opioids despite reported adherence to therapy.  Opioid overdose frequently occurs in individuals who are not prescribed the medication but obtained it from others; when diversion is suspected, future prescriptions should be suspended.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Opioids

answerChoiceList.choice: Prescribe naloxone for home use and traveling

questionList.questionText: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of back pain.  The patient was seen 2 days ago in the emergency department for similar pain symptoms and was discharged on naproxen.  Medical history is significant for asthma, hepatitis C, and opioid use disorder.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 138/92 mm Hg, and pulse is 104/min.  The patient is irritable while his vital signs are being taken and angrily says to the nurse, "That medication I got was useless.  My pain is now 10 times worse."  His speech is very loud, filled with expletives, and disruptive to patients in adjacent rooms.  His fists are clenched.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of the patient interview?
questionList.explanationText:
Aggressive patient in the emergency department

Risk factors

  • History of violent behavior/antisocial personality disorder 
  • Psychiatric illness (eg, psychosis, delirium, suicidal/homicidal ideation)
  • Substance use; acute intoxication, withdrawal
  • Prolonged wait times

Warning signs

  • Angry, irritable demeanor
  • Loud, aggressive speech, cursing, verbal threats
  • Tense posture, clenched fists, pacing
  • Desk or wall pounding, throwing objects

Management

  • Maintain a distance of 2 arm lengths; avoid direct eye contact
  • Interview with door open, clinician closer to the exit
  • Verbal deescalation
    • Use calm voice, nonconfrontational approach
    • Provide for basic needs (eg, offer food, drink, blanket)
    • Listen attentively to clarify patient's wants/needs
    • Set clear expectations that violence is unacceptable; reinforce that patient will not be harmed
    • Offer choices if appropriate (eg, oral vs intramuscular medications)
  • Chemical & physical restraint when verbal deescalation fails & violence is imminent

This patient is showing multiple signs of increasing agitation (eg, irritable demeanor, loud speech, cursing, clenched fists), which could escalate to violent behavior.  He is angry about his recent treatment in the emergency department and could pose a threat to staff if he feels his current needs are not being met.  Emergency department staff must be alert to verbal and nonverbal signs of escalating agitation and take steps to minimize safety risks to other patients and staff.

The most appropriate approach is to listen attentively to the patient's needs during the interview after arranging for security personnel to be standing nearby should the patient become violent.  In addition, the door should remain open so staff is not trapped behind a barrier with the patient.  Seating should be arranged so that the physician (not the patient) is seated closest to the exit to facilitate escape.  Objects that can be used as weapons should be removed from the room.  A panic button or agreed-upon code word can be used to alert security.

(Choice A)  Closing the door and asking the patient to calm down places the physician at increased risk.  Asking a patient to calm down can be perceived as condescending and have the unintended effect of making the patient angrier.  A closed door makes escape more difficult.

(Choice B)  Although it is appropriate to set limits that verbal abuse and violent behavior are unacceptable, threatening to withhold treatment is likely to be experienced as confrontational and may further escalate the situation.

(Choices C and D)  Informing the patient that he will be restrained or that security personnel will be called will likely make the patient feel that his needs are being ignored, leading to further agitation.  These statements may be perceived as confrontational and threatening and provoke the patient to act out violently so as to exert some control and prove himself.  It is safer to first try to engage the patient with a nonconfrontational approach and have the restraint team or security personnel nearby in case further intervention becomes necessary.

Educational objective:
Emergency department staff should be alert to verbal and nonverbal signs of escalating agitation and impending violence (eg, irritable demeanor, loud speech, cursing, tense posture, pacing, clenched fists).  Management techniques include interviewing the patient with the door open to facilitate escape by the clinician and a system for alerting security personnel standing nearby.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Aggression

answerChoiceList.choice: Close the patient's room door and ask him to calm down and lower his voice
Inform the patient that he will not be treated if he continues to be verbally abusive
Inform the patient that restraints will be applied if he loses control
Inform the patient that security personnel will be called if he continues to be aggressive
Interview the patient with the door open and have security personnel nearby

questionList.questionText: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her father due to bizarre behavior.  When the patient did not come down for breakfast this morning, her father went to her room and found her sitting up in bed, staring at the wall.  The patient did not respond to questions and was very stiff when her father tried to help her stand.  The patient was diagnosed with bipolar disorder last year.  She takes lithium, risperidone, and fluoxetine.  Her dosages of risperidone and fluoxetine were both increased recently to target residual depressive symptoms.  Temperature is 36.6 C (97.9 F), blood pressure is 121/78 mm Hg, pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 14/min.  When asked what today's date is, the patient repeats, "Date, date, date," repeatedly.  She resists the examiner's movement of her arms, increasing her resistance in proportion to the applied force.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Catatonia

Clinical features

  • Immobility or excessive purposeless activity 
  • Mutism, stupor (decreased alertness & response to stimuli)
  • Negativism (resistance to instructions & movement)
  • Posturing (assuming positions against gravity)
  • Waxy flexibility (initial resistance, then maintenance of new posture)
  • Echolalia, echopraxia (mimicking speech & movements)

Management

  • Benzodiazepines (lorazepam)
  • Electroconvulsive therapy

This patient's acute onset of immobility, mutism, negativism (ie, proportional resistance to passive movement), and echolalia (ie, repeating another's words) are consistent with catatonia.  Catatonia is a syndrome characterized by psychomotor signs/symptoms that occur in the context of psychiatric or medical illness.  Catatonia most often develops in the context of a mood disorder (eg, bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder); however, it may also occur in psychotic disorders (eg, schizophrenia), autism spectrum disorder, and general medical illness.

Catatonia is most often treated with benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam), but severe or intractable cases can be successfully treated with electroconvulsive therapy.  Relief of symptoms in response to a lorazepam challenge test (usually intravenous lorazepam) supports the diagnosis.

(Choice A)  Akinetic mutism is caused by lesions in the frontal cortex.  It may present similarly to catatonia but is not accompanied by echophenomena (eg, echolalia, echopraxia).

(Choice C)  Delirium is a disorder of acute onset altered attention and arousal that fluctuates in severity across time.  It would not explain this patient's motor symptoms or echophenomena.

(Choice D)  Drug-induced parkinsonism presents with resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity; it is most often caused by dopamine-blocking agents (eg, antipsychotics).  This patient's presentation, which includes mutism and echolalia, is better explained by catatonia.

(Choice E)  Locked-in syndrome is usually caused by a pontine stroke and presents with paralysis, mutism, and a preservation of cognitive abilities.

(Choice F)  Neuroleptic malignant syndrome presents with autonomic instability (eg, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension), rigidity, and altered mental status in the setting of antipsychotic medication use.  This patient is afebrile with normal vital signs.

(Choice G)  Serotonin syndrome is characterized by autonomic instability (eg, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension), hyperreflexia, and altered mental status in the context of serotonergic medication use.  It would not explain this patient's immobility, negativism, and normal vital signs.

Educational objective:
Catatonia is characterized by immobility, mutism, negativism, and echophenomena.  It most often presents in the context of bipolar disorder or major depressive disorder.  Catatonia is treated with benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam).

questionList.questionText: A 51-year-old man is evaluated for agitation and oppositional behavior.  The patient has a long history of schizophrenia.  He was admitted to a group home yesterday after his mother, with whom he previously lived, moved to an assisted care facility.  A staff member from the group home reports the patient was cooperative and calm when he arrived and did not talk much, which seems to be his baseline.  He did not sleep well last night, and today he has been pacing and yelling at other residents and staff.  The patient has no other medical conditions.  Medications include clozapine.  He does not use tobacco or recreational drugs but does use alcohol.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 152/94 mm Hg, and pulse is 114/min.  On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and diaphoretic and is fidgeting in his seat.  Marked hand tremors are present.  He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Although it can go unrecognized, substance use disorder often occurs in patients with schizophrenia; up to 50% of patients with newly diagnosed schizophrenia already have a diagnosis of alcohol or drug use disorder.  This patient with a history of schizophrenia and alcohol use has developed signs of alcohol withdrawal, likely precipitated by suddenly losing access to alcohol when he moved to a group home.  Clues to the diagnosis include the time course of symptoms (eg, calm and cooperative the first day, restless and agitated the second day) and manifestations of sympathetic hyperactivity (eg, elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and tremor).

Withdrawal symptoms typically start within 6-24 hours after the last drink.  Alcohol withdrawal seizures can occur within 12-48 hours, and delirium tremens (ie, disorientation, severe agitation, fever) typically begins within 48-96 hours.  Benzodiazepines are the treatment of choice for psychomotor agitation associated with alcohol withdrawal and to prevent progression to seizures and delirium.  Supportive psychological therapies may help with anxiety, but they do not slow the progression of alcohol withdrawal (Choice E).

(Choice A)  Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication sometimes used to treat antipsychotic-induced extrapyramidal symptoms (EPSs) such as akathisia (eg, restlessness) or parkinsonism (eg, tremor).  However, EPSs are most commonly associated with high-potency, first-generation antipsychotics (eg, haloperidol) rather than second-generation antipsychotics (eg, clozapine).  In addition, the hypertension, tachycardia, and diaphoresis exhibited by this patient are more consistent with alcohol withdrawal.

(Choice C)  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are indicated for major depression or anxiety disorders and take up to 2 weeks to take effect.  They would not be effective in managing acute anxiety or any adjustment symptoms resulting from the patient's move to the group home.  In addition, the diaphoresis and tremor suggest alcohol withdrawal rather than anxiety or adjustment symptoms.

(Choice D)  Discontinuing clozapine would be necessary if this patient had neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), a life-threatening condition associated with the use of antipsychotic agents.  NMS can present with agitation and autonomic instability (eg, tachycardia); however, hyperthermia and muscle rigidity are also typically present.  Clozapine is generally used in conditions refractory to other antipsychotic medications; its discontinuation in this patient would likely result in significant worsening of his psychiatric condition.

Educational objective:
Alcohol use disorder often goes unrecognized in patients with schizophrenia and should be considered in patients  who develop acute agitation, diaphoresis, tremor, elevated blood pressure, and tachycardia following admission to a supervised setting.  Benzodiazepines are the treatment of choice.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Alcohol withdrawal

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Alcohol withdrawal syndrome: diagnostic and therapeutic methods.

questionList.questionText: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to behavioral concerns.  The patient has been coming home after curfew most nights and arguing with his parents more than usual.  The mother notes that he has been spending most of his time at home alone in his room with the door closed and seems less interested in attending family get-togethers.  The mother also shares that she found a marijuana joint under the patient's bed last week; when asked about the joint, he stated it belongs to a friend and he does not use drugs.  The patient maintains a B average in school and plays in the high school band.  When interviewed alone, the patient states he has tried marijuana a few times and lied to his mother because he was afraid that she would tell his father.  The patient says he would rather avoid talking to his father for as long as possible and shares that his father refers to him as a disappointment.  He has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications.  Vital signs are normal; growth curves are tracking consistently.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This adolescent's behavioral concerns appear to center around his relationship with his parents (ie, lying to his mother, breaking curfew rules, increased arguing, avoiding conversations with his father).  When seen individually, he expresses fear about his father's judgments and reactions.  The most appropriate approach is to conceptualize the patient's behavior in a family context and to recommend family therapy with the goal of improving communication between the patient and his parents and resolving family conflict.  Rather than pathologizing the adolescent as the identified patient, this approach is a means of helping the entire family improve their communication and conflict resolution skills and develop mutual understanding and respect.

Family therapy is conducted by a trained family therapist and focuses on changing dysfunctional patterns of interaction among family members to enhance family functioning.  The therapist can help family members resolve disagreements about rules and expectations and develop strategies to defuse escalating arguments.  Family therapy has been shown to increase positive outcomes in adolescent behavioral problems, substance use disorders, and depression.

(Choice A)  This patient is having significant difficulty communicating with his father.  Simply encouraging the patient to communicate more with his father places the burden on the patient to resolve the family dysfunction.  In addition, this would likely lead only to the patient and his father reenacting their conflicts.  Family therapy, in which a therapist can observe the interactions and facilitate communication between family members, would be more likely to resolve the conflict.

(Choice B)  This patient's behavior (eg, avoidance of the father, withdrawal from the family) is not normal, and the current dysfunctional interaction between the patient and his parents is unlikely to improve without therapeutic intervention.

(Choice D)  Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor indicated for the treatment of moderate to severe pediatric depression.  This patient lacks key features of depression (eg, loss of interest, sleep and appetite disturbance, lethargy, suicidality); his change in behavior appears to be in response to a strained relationship with his father.

(Choice E)  This patient has been open with the physician about his experimentation with marijuana and shows no signs of drug abuse or dependence that would necessitate referral for drug counseling.  This approach would mistakenly conceptualize the concern as a substance use issue and fail to address the dysfunctional family dynamics.

Educational objective:
Family therapy is a type of counseling that focuses on changing dysfunctional patterns of interaction among family members to enhance family functioning.  It has been shown to increase positive outcomes in adolescent behavioral problems, substance use disorders, and depression.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Child and adolescent mental health

answerChoiceList.choice: Encourage the patient to communicate more with his father
Provide reassurance that the patient's behaviors are age-appropriate

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The effectiveness of functional family therapy for adolescent behavioral and substance misuse problems: a meta-analysis.
Overview of the evidence base for family interventions in child psychiatry.

questionList.questionText: A 44-year-old man comes to the office for routine follow-up.  Medical history is significant for mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and major depressive disorder.  The patient has smoked a half-pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years.  He has attempted to quit smoking several times in the past year.  He is frustrated by his inability to maintain abstinence for more than a few days, saying, "I just always go right back to the same thing."  The patient has recently started taking varenicline and nicotine replacement therapy again.  He participates in a social support group whenever his schedule allows and has called the tobacco cessation hotline occasionally.  The patient is unsure what triggers his relapse, but he thinks that stress might be a factor.  Which of the following counseling strategies is the best next step to promote successful smoking cessation in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Smoking cessation interventions by stage of change

Not ready to quit

  • Conduct motivational interviewing (4R): relevance, risks, rewards, roadblocks
  • Repeat at every visit
  • Prescribe varenicline* to facilitate reduce-to-quit strategy

Ready to quit

  • Set a firm quit date & discard smoking paraphernalia
  • Provide behavioral counseling & engage support systems
  • Prescribe pharmacotherapy (eg, varenicline, bupropion, NRT)

Struggling to quit

  • Reinforce partial achievements
  • Identify triggers & link them to other (distracting) activities
  • Use biofeedback loops (eg, exhaled CO monitoring, gamification using mobile app)

Recently quit

  • Congratulate & offer continued support
  • Continue pharmacotherapy for 12 weeks
  • Encourage active reflection (anticipated problems, "how has your life changed?")

*2-fold higher rate of durable abstinence.

CO = carbon monoxide; NRT = nicotine replacement therapy.

Tobacco addiction encompasses physical nicotine dependency (eg, withdrawal, cravings), psychological reliance (eg, smoking to relieve stress), and habitual behavior (eg, automatically smoking after a meal).  Pharmacotherapy helps alleviate withdrawal (eg, nicotine replacement) and cravings (eg, varenicline, bupropion).  However, patients often need behavioral counseling and other forms of assistance to address the psychological and habitual motivations to smoke.

This patient is in the process of smoking cessation.  He is action oriented (eg, adherent to pharmacotherapy, participating in support group) but struggling with early relapses in part due to stress.  In this active stage of change, the physician's role is to help the patient develop specific strategies to quit.

Most urges to smoke are transient, lasting between 5 and 10 minutes.  One of the most powerful behavioral strategies involves identifying the habitual triggers (eg, morning coffee, bowel movement, driving) and linking them to alternative, distracting activities (eg, flossing teeth, chewing gum).  Ideally, the patient will propose the alternative activities.  This strategy of trigger-behavior linking is even more effective when applied to the first cigarette of the day.  The ability to delay the time to first cigarette is a strong predictor of success.

(Choice A)  Listing benefits and drawbacks of smoking is a component of motivational interviewing for patients in the precontemplative and early contemplative stages of change (ie, not ready to quit).  This patient is in the action stage; he has already internalized the benefits of smoking cessation but needs behavioral assistance to meet his goal.

(Choice C)  A firm quit date is a key first step for every cessation attempt.  However, this patient has early relapses; missing another quit date will likely lead to disappointment and reinforce his cycle of frustration.

(Choice D)  Life stressors are nearly universal experiences for patients attempting to quit smoking.  A key component of smoking cessation is helping patients manage stress by choosing healthier coping habits.  Moreover, having "minimal" stress is not a reasonable expectation.

(Choice E)  Frightening images (eg, oral cancer, blackened lungs) may deter some patients from smoking.  Others choose to tape a picture of their children or other loved ones to the cigarette carton.  This tactic is rooted in eliciting guilt, which may be effective for deciding to quit acutely.  However, it is unlikely to modify trigger responses and habits, which is critical for creating lasting change.

Educational objective:
For patients who are in the active stage of smoking cessation but struggling with relapses, a powerful behavioral strategy is to identify habitual triggers for smoking (especially for the first cigarette of the day) and then link them to alternative distracting activities.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Smoking Cessation

answerChoiceList.choice: Ask the patient to list 3 benefits and 3 drawbacks of smoking cessation
Inquire about the patient's activities while smoking his first cigarette of the day
Mutually decide on a new quit date and tell the patient to mark it on his calendar
Recommend delaying smoking cessation until he is under minimal life stress
Urge the patient to tape a picture of his children to the front of the cigarette box

questionList.questionText: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to concerns about his anxiety and adjustment to school.  Six months ago, the patient started a new school that requires him to change classrooms for different subjects.  The mother says that he has always been shy and had difficulty making friends.  She says that the change has been stressful for him and has not become easier over time.  The patient reads at grade level and does well in math; however, he has difficulty in classes that require oral participation or group involvement and gets into trouble because he blurts out answers.  The patient's behavior outside school causes problems as well.  Last week, when morning traffic required departing from routine by taking a different route to school, he became agitated and threw his school bag, hitting his brother in the face.  While the mother is speaking, the patient interrupts to say that he would rather read about astronomy on his own because school is "a stupid waste of time."  Physical examination is remarkable for a repetitive opening and closing motion of his hands—which becomes more intense when he is asked about school—but is otherwise normal.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's behavior?
questionList.explanationText:
Autism spectrum disorder

Clinical features

  • Social deficits with onset in early development
    • Difficulty sharing emotions or interests
    • Lack of nonverbal communication (eg, eye contact)
    • Difficulty developing/understanding relationships 
  • Restricted, repetitive behaviors & interests
    • Repetitive movements (eg, hand-flapping) or speech
    • Insistence on sameness/routines
    • Intense, fixated interests
    • Adverse responses to sensory input (eg, foods, textures)
  • ± Language delays & cognitive impairment 

Evaluation

  • Comprehensive clinical evaluation
  • Genetic testing (eg, chromosomal microarray, fragile X gene analysis)
  • ± Brain MRI (eg, macrocephaly, neurologic deficits)
   Management 
  • Behavioral, speech, occupational therapies

This patient has:

  • difficulty navigating social interactions (difficulty making friends, struggles in group activities, and interrupting others).
  • inability to tolerate changes in routine (changing classrooms and alternate school routes).
  • repetitive movements (opening and closing his hands).

These features are suggestive of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

Patients with milder autism frequently have normal or near-normal language and intellectual ability that may lead to a delay in diagnosis (whereas more severe ASD is usually diagnosed by age 5).  However, as social expectations increase with age, deficits in social awareness and interpersonal skills become more noticeable.

Concerning features include inability to interpret and respond appropriately to nonverbal cues; abnormal eye contact; intense, perseverative interests or one-sided conversations; difficulties understanding sarcasm, metaphors, or humor; and abnormal sensory sensitivity.  In addition, changes in routines commonly cause anxiety and can provoke agitation or behavioral dysregulation (such as this patient's bag throwing).

(Choice A)  This patient's social deficits have become more apparent with the increased demands of his new school.  Stressors often exacerbate the symptoms of a preexisting condition; however, his difficulties are preexisting manifestations of ASD (always had difficulty making friends) and not simply a time-limited response to a stressor as seen in adjustment disorder.

(Choice B)  This patient's blurting out of answers is likely due to difficulty interpreting and responding appropriately to social cues.  He does not display multiple symptoms of hyperactivity, impulsivity, and/or impaired attention in multiple settings to warrant a separate diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

(Choice D)  Patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) can also present with rigid adherence to specific routines.  However, this patient lacks the intrusive obsessional thoughts and corresponding compulsive rituals characteristic of OCD.

(Choice E)  This patient's outbursts are a response to difficulty tolerating change or navigating social cues.  He does not display the pattern of willful disregard for authority or vindictiveness seen in oppositional defiant disorder.

(Choice F)  Tourette syndrome is characterized by multiple motor and vocal tics, often with premonitory urge, which can worsen with stress.  However, this patient's motor stereotypy helps him self-soothe during distressing thoughts about school.  Furthermore, social deficits and insistence on routine are not consistent with Tourette syndrome.

Educational objective:
Autism spectrum disorder is characterized by social deficits, behavioral rigidity with resistance to change, and repetitive movements.  Onset is in early development; however, patients with normal language and intellectual ability may be diagnosed later, when social demands make deficits more apparent.

questionList.title: Autism spectrum disorders

Anxiety disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorder in individuals with autism spectrum disorder.
Social anxiety in children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorders contribute to impairments in social communication and social motivation.

questionList.questionText: A 46-year-old man is hospitalized due to suicidal ideation and hearing voices.  The patient has become increasingly depressed over the past month and has been unable to work.  Last week he told his wife that he was "tormented by voices" and that "death would be a relief."  She brought him to the hospital after she found him staring at a blank screen on the television and not responding to her questions.  The patient was prescribed risperidone, lithium, and escitalopram by his psychiatrist, but his wife is unsure if he takes them regularly.  He has a history of bipolar disorder since age 18 with multiple hospitalizations for both manic and depressive episodes.  His other medical problems are hypercholesterolemia and seasonal allergies.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 12/min.  Routine laboratory results are within normal limits, lithium level is within therapeutic range, and a toxicology screen is negative.  During the evaluation, the patient stares blankly and is mute and motionless.  He resists all instructions to move.  When the physician lifts the patient's arm, it remains in the exact same position after she lets go.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Catatonia

Clinical features

  • Immobility or excessive purposeless activity 
  • Mutism, stupor (decreased alertness & response to stimuli)
  • Negativism (resistance to instructions & movement)
  • Posturing (assuming positions against gravity)
  • Waxy flexibility (initial resistance, then maintenance of new posture)
  • Echolalia, echopraxia (mimicking speech & movements)

Management

  • Benzodiazepines (lorazepam)
  • Electroconvulsive therapy

This patient's history of severe bipolar disorder and current immobility and mutism are suggestive of catatonia.  Catatonia is a syndrome (not a specific disorder) of marked psychomotor disturbance that occurs in severely ill patients with mood disorders with psychotic features, psychotic disorders, autism spectrum disorder, and medical conditions (infectious, metabolic, neurologic, rheumatologic).  Common features include decreased motor activity, lack of responsiveness during interview, posturing, and waxy flexibility (initial resistance to repositioning by the examiner, followed by maintenance of new repositioned posture).  Catatonia can range from stupor to marked agitation (catatonic excitement), which contributes to difficulty in recognition.

Treatment of catatonia includes benzodiazepines (most commonly lorazepam) and/or electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).  A lorazepam challenge test (intravenous lorazepam 1-2 mg) resulting in partial, temporary relief within 5-10 minutes confirms the diagnosis.  Catatonia generally responds to lorazepam within a week; ECT is the treatment of choice in patients who do not improve.

(Choice A)  Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication used to treat extrapyramidal side effects (eg, acute dystonic reaction, parkinsonism) of antipsychotic medications.  This patient's complete immobility, mutism with lack of responsiveness, and waxy flexibility are more characteristic of catatonia.

(Choices B and E)  Antipsychotics can worsen catatonia and should be avoided.  Clozapine is generally reserved for treatment-refractory psychosis due to the risk of severe neutropenia.  Treatment of this patient's underlying bipolar disorder with risperidone should be deferred until his catatonia resolves with lorazepam.

(Choice C)  The serotonin antagonist cyproheptadine has been used to treat severe cases of serotonin syndrome, which is characterized by a triad of autonomic instability, altered mental status, and neuromuscular irritability.

(Choice D)  Dantrolene has been used to treat muscular rigidity associated with severe neuroleptic malignant syndrome that does not respond to discontinuation of antipsychotic medication.  This syndrome is characterized by fever, diffuse muscular rigidity, autonomic instability, and significant laboratory abnormalities (eg, elevated creatine kinase).  It is unlikely in this patient, who has stable vital signs.

Educational objective:
Catatonia is a syndrome seen in severe psychiatric and medical illness and is characterized by immobility, mutism, and posturing.  Lorazepam and electroconvulsive therapy are the treatments of choice.

questionList.title: Catatonia
