The Use of Lorazepam and Electroconvulsive Therapy in the Treatment of Catatonia: Treatment Characteristics and Outcomes in 60 Patients.
A clinical review of the treatment of catatonia.

questionList.questionText: A 46-year-old man is admitted to the hospital due to cellulitis of the right hand.  He has a history of intravenous drug use, alcohol use disorder, and septic arthritis of the knee.  Treatment with vancomycin is initiated.  The day after admission, the cellulitis has improved; however, the patient now reports that he sees bats flying around his room.  He says that he has never before experienced visual hallucinations.  Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 131/89 mm Hg, pulse is 93/min, and respirations are 18/min.  Examination shows decreased swelling and redness of the right hand, mild tremors bilaterally, and diaphoresis.  The patient is alert and oriented but appears frightened.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?
questionList.explanationText:
The abrupt onset of hallucinations in this patient with a known history of alcohol use disorder and classic signs of alcohol withdrawal (eg, tremors, diaphoresis) after a period of forced abstinence (ie, admission to the hospital) is consistent with alcoholic hallucinosis.  Alcoholic hallucinosis usually presents within 24 hours of the last drink and most commonly causes visual hallucinations (eg, bats flying around the room), although tactile and auditory hallucinations are also possible.

Patients with alcoholic hallucinosis are typically alert, with intact cognition and awareness, despite the presence of distressing hallucinations.  In contrast, patients with delirium tremens (DT) typically have confusion and disorientation with severe autonomic hyperactivity (eg, high fever, hypertension); hallucinations in DT typically occur >48 hours after the last drink.

Patients with alcohol withdrawal should be treated with benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam) to control symptoms and prevent progression of withdrawal (eg, seizures, DT), which can be life-threatening.  DT is associated with a mortality rate as high as 5% (Choice D).

(Choice A)  Antipsychotics such as haloperidol are not indicated for the treatment of alcoholic hallucinosis, which resolves with treatment of the underlying alcohol withdrawal.  Antipsychotics may lower the seizure threshold and should be avoided in the seizure-prone state of alcohol withdrawal.

(Choice C)  Adverse effects of vancomycin include ototoxicity, vancomycin infusion reaction (a pseudoallergic reaction characterized by flushing and pruritus), and nephrotoxicity.  Vancomycin is improving this patient's infection and is not causing his symptoms.

(Choice E)  This patient has no localizing signs or symptoms that suggest a neurologic lesion and exhibits classic signs of alcohol withdrawal.  CT scan of the head is not indicated unless withdrawal treatment fails to resolve his symptoms or new neurologic deficits develop.

Educational objective:
Alcoholic hallucinosis usually presents within 24 hours after the last drink and is typically associated with other symptoms of alcohol withdrawal (eg, tremor, diaphoresis).  Treatment consists of benzodiazepines to control symptoms and prevent the progression of withdrawal.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Alcohol withdrawal

answerChoiceList.choice: Obtain a CT scan of the head

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Management of acute alcohol withdrawal syndrome in critically ill patients.
Alcohol withdrawal syndrome: benzodiazepines and beyond.

questionList.questionText:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the office due to insomnia and fatigue that began shortly after her divorce was finalized a year ago.  The patient used to sleep 7-8 hours without difficulty; however, over the past year she has had increasing difficulty falling asleep and started drinking 2-3 glasses of wine before bedtime to help.  Despite falling asleep more quickly, she has recently started to regularly wake up around 3:00 AM.  Her symptoms have progressively worsened and she now lies awake for several hours in the middle of the night, thinking and worrying about her future, but she rarely experiences anxiety during the day.  She reports mild difficulty with concentration and no change in appetite.  The patient experiences occasional brief sadness and loneliness.  She has recently started showing up late for work and has stopped attending her weekly exercise class.  Medical history includes hypothyroidism, treated with levothyroxine, and gastroesophageal reflux disease, diagnosed 3 months ago and treated with famotidine.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 12/min.  Physical examination shows a mild tremor but no other abnormalities.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin11.4 g/dL
    Hematocrit34%
    Mean corpuscular volume106 µm3
    Platelets150,000/mm3
    Leukocytes7,500/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium142 mEq/L
    Potassium3.9 mEq/L
    Chloride102 mEq/L
    Bicarbonate26 mEq/L
    Blood urea nitrogen20 mg/dL
    Creatinine0.8 mg/dL
    Glucose100 mg/dL
Liver function studies
    Total protein6.5 g/dL
    Total bilirubin0.7 mg/dL
    Alkaline phosphatase78 U/L
    Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)85 U/L
    Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)42 U/L
Endocrine
    TSH2.7 µU/mL

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
The National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism has found evidence of negative health effects for women of all ages and men age ≥65 who consume >7 drinks in a week or >3 in a day (for men age <65, the cutoffs are >14 drinks in a week or >4 drinks in a day).  This patient's alcohol consumption pattern (≥14 drinks per week), abnormal liver enzymes (aspartate aminotransferase/alanine aminotransferase ratio ≥2:1), macrocytosis, alcohol tolerance (ie, decreasing sedative effects of alcohol over time), and impaired functioning (eg, work tardiness) are consistent with a diagnosis of alcohol use disorder.  This diagnosis is also supported by her history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and hypertension as well as a tremor on examination.

Individuals with alcohol use disorder frequently seek primary care due to sleep disturbance and/or anxiety symptoms from mild withdrawal, as in this patient.  These individuals may use alcohol to fall asleep, but as the blood alcohol level drops, CNS hyperarousal occurs and results in awakenings.

(Choice A)  Although this patient's alcohol use may have initially escalated in response to her divorce a year ago, adjustment disorder cannot be diagnosed in a patient whose symptoms have lasted >6 months after a stressor.

(Choice C)  There is insufficient evidence that this patient's insomnia and anxiety are a direct result of the physiological effects of a medical condition.  Her normal TSH level indicates that her hypothyroidism is well controlled.

(Choice D)  Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by pervasive and excessive worry about multiple issues and is typically seen in patients who report lifelong anxiety.  It is less likely in this patient with signs/symptoms of alcohol use disorder, no history of psychiatric illness, and circumscribed anxiety (ie, only worries at night when unable to sleep).

(Choice E)  Although this patient may have initially developed difficulty falling asleep in the context of a divorce, it developed into a classic pattern of alcohol-induced sleep disruption with the onset of heavy drinking.  Insomnia disorder is diagnosed only when the sleep disturbance is not better explained by another disorder.

(Choice F)  A diagnosis of dysthymia would require a depressed mood for at least 2 years and substance-induced causes to be ruled out.

Educational objective:
Patients with unhealthy alcohol use are frequently seen in the primary care setting for insomnia and/or anxiety.  These patients should be carefully screened for alcohol use disorder.  Findings of increased liver enzymes and macrocytosis can also assist in screening.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Alcohol use disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Anxiety disorder due to another medical condition

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Alcohol dependence and its relationship with insomnia and other sleep disorders.
Screening for substance abuse in women's health:  a public health imperative.
Screening for alcohol and drug use disorders among adults in primary care:  a review.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old man comes to the office due to recent insomnia.  The patient has experienced stress at his job in the past month because he has had to work extra hours on multiple occasions while several coworkers have been on vacation or sick.  Over the past 2 weeks, he has had difficulty falling asleep most nights and has been fatigued throughout the day.  Recently, the patient has started drinking 1 or 2 beers at night to help him fall asleep as well as energy drinks throughout the day to stay alert.  He describes feeling anxious and irritable and has experienced occasional palpitations and feelings of panic.  The patient has a history of depression.  He does not use illicit drugs.  Blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse is 95/min.  On examination, the patient is restless and mildly tremulous with a flushed and agitated appearance, irritable mood, and rapid speech.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's insomnia, anxiety, palpitations, hypertension, and tremulousness are suggestive of caffeine intoxication, likely due to his recent excessive consumption of energy drinks.  Energy drinks frequently contain high quantities of caffeine and may lead to toxicity when consumed in excess.

Caffeine is a stimulant that, when used excessively, can result in insomnia, jitteriness, anxiety, gastrointestinal symptoms, and headaches, as well as more serious adverse effects including tachycardia, hypertension, panic attacks, agitation, psychosis, and seizures.  Energy drink consumption is especially popular among adolescents and young men, and it should be considered in anyone with signs or symptoms of stimulant intoxication.

(Choices A and F)  Adjustment and primary anxiety (eg, panic) disorders are diagnoses of exclusion that would not be diagnosed when symptoms are more likely to be substance-induced.

(Choice B)  Alcohol withdrawal can also result in anxiety, insomnia, tremulousness, hypertension, and palpitations.  However, it is usually associated with heavy drinking and other signs of dependence.  The amount that this patient is drinking would be very unlikely to lead to withdrawal; furthermore, his history is more consistent with caffeine intoxication from energy drinks.

(Choice D)  Although covering several different shifts at work could explain this patient's insomnia, it would not explain his daytime anxiety, restlessness, tremors, or palpitations, which are more consistent with caffeine intoxication.

(Choice E)  A hypomanic episode can include insomnia, irritability, and pressured speech, but this patient lacks other characteristic hypomanic symptoms (eg, elevated mood, increased energy, grandiosity).  It would not explain this patient's prominent signs of sympathetic stimulation.

Educational objective:
Caffeine is a stimulant that, when used in excessive amounts, can cause sympathetic hyperactivity, leading to anxiety, jitteriness, insomnia, palpitations, and tremors.  Energy drinks typically contain large amounts of caffeine and should be considered as a cause of stimulant intoxication.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Stimulants

answerChoiceList.choice: Circadian sleep-wake rhythm disorder, shift work type

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The clinical toxicology of caffeine: a review and case study.
Caffeinated energy drink consumption among adolescents and potential health consequences associated with their use: a significant public health hazard.
Energy drinks and their adverse health effects: a systematic review of the current evidence.

questionList.questionText: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the office by her father after getting suspended from her new school for pushing a peer while waiting in line at the cafeteria.  There has been a history of behavioral concerns since first grade, and the parents have received occasional calls home from the teacher for talking back and refusing to stay in her seat.  Her father reports that the patient has always had a lot of energy and "needs to be active to stay out of trouble."  The patient requires frequent prompting to complete homework assignments and forgets to do her chores.  The father states, "My daughter doesn't think before she speaks or acts, but this is the first really bad thing she has done.  Her dog died last month, and she's been pretty upset."  Family history is significant for bipolar disorder in her mother.  On examination, the patient is mildly restless and talkative.  She says her mood is "fine" except for missing her dog and that she "hates school because it's so boring."  Which of the following is the most appropriate statement?
questionList.explanationText:
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

Clinical
features

  • Inattentive &/or hyperactive/impulsive symptoms for ≥6 months
    • Inattentive symptoms: difficulty focusing, distractible, does not listen or follow instructions, disorganized, forgetful, loses/misplaces objects
    • Hyperactive/impulsive symptoms: fidgety, unable to sit still, "driven by a motor," hypertalkative, interrupts, blurts out answers
  • Several symptoms present before age 12
  • Symptoms occur in at least 2 settings (home, school) & cause functional impairment
  • Subtypes: predominantly inattentive, predominantly hyperactive/impulsive, combined type

Treatment

  • Stimulants (methylphenidate, amphetamines)
  • Nonstimulants (atomoxetine, α-2 adrenergic agonists)
  • Behavioral therapy

The description of this child's behavior is suggestive of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

Symptoms of ADHD are present across ≥2 settings (ie, home, school) and include inattentive features (eg, forgetting chores, trouble completing tasks without repeated prompting) and hyperactive/impulsive characteristics (eg, unable to sit still, not thinking before reacting).  In some children, unmanaged symptoms can escalate to outbursts of frustration (eg, pushing a peer), as in this case.  Structured behavioral observations of symptoms obtained via teacher and parent rating scales support the diagnosis.

Stimulants (eg, methylphenidates, amphetamines) are the first-line treatment of ADHD in school-aged children and adolescents due to their rapid onset of action, effectiveness, and tolerability.  As core ADHD symptoms improve with stimulants, impulsive outbursts, academic productivity, and parent-child interactions generally improve as well.  Common adverse effects include insomnia or appetite suppression, which can be addressed by adjusting the timing of dose administration (eg, morning/after breakfast).

(Choice A)  ADHD is a chronic neurodevelopmental disorder, and most symptoms manifest through adolescence into adulthood.  This patient's symptoms are causing impairment and are not expected to spontaneously remit.

(Choice C)  Sudden or new stressors (eg, pet dying, starting a new school) can lead to mood and behavioral changes in children.  However, this patient's long-standing history of hyperactive/impulsive symptoms with recent worsening behavior suggests a chronic, unmanaged condition (ie, ADHD).

(Choice D)  Behavioral therapy (eg, parent management training) is an adjunct in ADHD treatment, but this intervention alone does not sufficiently manage core ADHD symptoms in school-aged children and adolescents, for whom stimulants are first-line.  Behavioral therapy is also used to treat conduct disorder, which can manifest with conflicts with others, but this patient lacks the characteristic exploitative behaviors reflecting a disregard for others.  Moreover, her behavioral concerns appear to be related to impulsivity, a finding consistent with ADHD.

(Choice E)  Mania in bipolar disorder (eg, increased energy, distractibility) is typically episodic, occurring in distinct periods (eg, 1 week at a time).  Although this patient has a positive family history and is described as talkative and energetic, the persistent and nonepisodic nature of her symptoms suggests an alternate diagnosis.

Educational objective:
Stimulants are the first-line treatment for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in school-aged children.  The presentation includes inattentive features (eg, forgetfulness) and hyperactive/impulsive symptoms (eg, excessively energetic) that may escalate into outbursts of frustration when untreated.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: "Let's see how she does over the next year; most children outgrow these behaviors by adolescence and do not require treatment."
"She seems to have difficulty with focus and impulse control, which is likely due to a disorder for which there are very effective medications."
"Starting at a new school and losing a pet can be difficult for many children; she is likely experiencing an adjustment period that does not require medication."
"There are no medications that have been proved effective for your daughter's aggression, although a parent-child therapy program may improve her behavior."
"Your daughter's behavior may be a sign of early-onset bipolar disorder; fortunately, this is highly treatable with medication."

questionList.questionText:
Patient Information
Age: 21 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Site of Care: emergency department

History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: seizure
History of Present Illness:

  • brought by ambulance after a witnessed seizure 30 minutes ago
  • history obtained from his family
  • just returned from a party with friends and was "not acting like himself" prior to the seizure

Past Medical History:

  • major depressive disorder
  • no previous seizures

Medications:

  • sertraline

Allergies:

  • no known drug allergies

Family History:

  • noncontributory

Psychosocial History:

  • is a college student
  • occasionally drinks beer
  • does not use tobacco
  • recreational drug use unknown

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO2 SatHtWtBMI
40 C
(104 F)		120/min16/min170/96
mm Hg		98%
on RA		––23 kg/m2
  • Appearance: flushed; diaphoretic
  • Pulmonary: clear lungs
  • Cardiac: tachycardic with regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2
  • Abdominal: increased bowel sounds; soft and nontender; no hepatosplenomegaly
  • Neurologic: deep tendon reflexes are 3+ and symmetric in all extremities; spontaneous myoclonus in the upper extremities; minimally responsive to painful stimuli

Diagnostic Studies

Hematocrit48%
Na+122 mEq/L
K+3.6 mEq/L
Cl−98 mEq/L
HCO3−20 mEq/L
Glucose90 mg/dL
Creatinine1.0 mg/dL
  • CT scan of the head: no acute infarction, hemorrhage, or mass lesion

Question: Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Intoxication syndromes in drugs of abuse

Drug

Clinical features

NMDA antagonists
(eg, PCP, ketamine)

  • Violent behavior
  • Dissociation
  • Hallucinations
  • Amnesia
  • Nystagmus (horizontal or vertical)
  • Ataxia

MDMA (ecstasy)

  • Euphoria
  • Tachycardia/hypertension
  • Hyperthermia
  • Serotonin toxicity
  • Hyponatremia
  • Seizures
  • Mydriasis

Benzodiazepines

  • CNS depression
  • Normal vital signs
  • Slurred speech
  • Ataxia
  • Coma

Opioid narcotics
(eg,oxycodone)

  • Euphoria
  • Depressed mental status
  • Respiratory depression
  • Miosis
  • Constipation

MDMA = 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine;
NMDA = N-methyl-D-aspartate; PCP = phencyclidine.

This patient's presentation suggests MDMA intoxication complicated by serotonin syndrome.  MDMA, formulated as ecstasy or Molly, has mild hallucinogenic properties and is sometimes used by college students during parties to cause euphoria and increase sociability, alertness, empathy, and sexual desire.

MDMA is a synthetic amphetamine that exerts its effects by increasing synaptic levels of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin.  Severe intoxication may manifest with features of:

  • sympathomimetic toxicity: hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and hyperthermia.

  • serotonin toxicity: serotonin syndrome (eg, altered mental status, hyperreflexia, myoclonus, seizures) and hyponatremia (due to drug-induced inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion as well as excessive water intake to reduce hyperthermia).

Combining MDMA with other serotonergic drugs (eg, sertraline), as in this patient, further increases the risk of serotonin syndrome.  Coma and death may result from acute intoxication, and long-term use has been linked to neurotoxicity.  Recreational synthetic amphetamines and analogues (eg, MDMA, bath salts) may not show up as amphetamines in routine urine toxicology screens.

(Choice A)  Symptoms of alcohol withdrawal may include tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, delirium, and seizures, but myoclonus is not expected.  In addition, this patient drinks alcohol only occasionally, making withdrawal less likely.

(Choice B)  Cannabis intoxication can cause tachycardia and hypertension but typically not hyperthermia; neurologic manifestations (eg, slurred speech and ataxia) may also result, but seizures, myoclonus, or hyperreflexia are usually not seen.

(Choice C)  Diphenhydramine overdose leading to anticholinergic toxicity can cause bizarre behavior, flushing, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, and seizures.  However, affected patients typically have anhidrosis and decreased bowel sounds, whereas this patient is diaphoretic with increased bowel sounds.

(Choice E)  Nitrous oxide is an inhalant sometimes misused for its euphoric and calming properties.  It can cause loss of consciousness and seizures (with significant overdoses), but elevated vital signs, myoclonus, hyperreflexia, and hyponatremia are not expected.  In addition, its effects typically last only 15-45 minutes.

(Choice F)  Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication most often induces severe agitation, psychosis, and aggressive behavior rather than somnolence.  Although seizures can occur with large overdoses, they are not typical.

Educational objective:
MDMA is a synthetic amphetamine that can cause euphoria and increased sociability, empathy, and sexual desire.  Because it increases synaptic levels of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, intoxication may manifest with sympathomimetic toxicity (eg, tachycardia, hypertension) and serotonin syndrome (eg, seizures, myoclonus).  Use with other serotonergic drugs greatly increases the risk of serotonin syndrome.

questionList.title: Substance use disorders

questionList.questionText: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up of chronic tension-type headaches.  Her headaches have not improved after several trials of medications, including those recommended by a neurologist specializing in the management of headaches.  The patient says, "I'm really not surprised that this last medication didn't work either.  All these drug companies just want to make money.  I doubt that anything will help."  When asked if she would consider pursuing biofeedback, relaxation training, or stress management therapy, she responds, "There's no point—how can I relax or do therapy when my head is pounding?"  The patient's other medical problems include hypertension and hypercholesterolemia, which are well controlled with medication.  She has a history of depression following her divorce in her 40s but was unwilling to take an antidepressant or see a counselor at that time.  Which of the following statements is the most appropriate response to this patient's concerns?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient remains symptomatic despite the best efforts of the physician to treat her with multiple medication trials, and she rejects all recommended nonpharmacological approaches.  Such patients believe that no treatment will help and appear not to want to improve.  They are often frustrating to manage and can leave the physician feeling angry and manipulated.  The understandable tendency to want to refer this patient to another provider or specialist should be avoided (Choice E).

These patients often have underlying depression but will refuse referral to a psychiatrist.  They are needy for attention and unconsciously wish to remain symptomatic so that they can continue to see a physician.  The best approach is to empathize with them and attempt to engage them in a collaborative plan in which there is mutual agreement about realistic treatment approaches and limited expectations.  Empathizing with the patient's frustration over disappointing outcomes and focusing on alleviation of symptoms rather than a cure is often helpful.

(Choices A and C)  There is insufficient information on this patient to diagnose depression, and she would likely reject this explanation of her poor response.  She has previously rejected counseling and is currently resistant to other treatment approaches; therefore, she is unlikely to agree to counseling at this stage.

(Choice B)  This statement attempts to confront this patient by pointing out her help-rejecting pattern of behavior.  This would likely be perceived as judgmental, resulting in loss of rapport and defensiveness.  However, it could be useful as part of a therapeutic intervention by a skilled therapist in the context of structured psychotherapy.

(Choice F)  The physician has already encouraged the patient to consider nonpharmacological approaches.  Rather than continuing to make treatment recommendations that will likely be rejected, the physician should develop a collaborative focus on a small goal that she identifies.

Educational objective:
Help-rejecting patients who are hopeless about treatment can lead the physician to become frustrated and confrontational and to desire to refer the patient to another provider.  Clear expression of empathy and a collaborative approach with limited goals are the most effective approaches.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Physician patient communication

answerChoiceList.choice: I am concerned that depression is contributing to your hopelessness about getting better.
I can see that it has been frustrating, but let's explore why you seem to reject every new suggestion.
I can see that you are feeling hopeless; talking with a counselor may help improve your outlook.
I can see that your lack of improvement has been frustrating; let's identify a small goal we can agree on.
I share your frustration; let's obtain a second opinion from a psychiatrist who may help identify new treatment strategies.
It must be frustrating that medications have not helped; I encourage you to reconsider biofeedback and relaxation training.

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Managing difficult encounters: understanding physician, patient, and situational factors.

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police officers after he was found wandering aimlessly at an airport.  The man is alert and answers questions appropriately; however, he appears to be confused about his identity and does not recognize the name on his Nevada driver's license in his wallet.  Extensive inquiry fails to reveal any helpful information as the patient is perplexed and does not remember where he lives, how he got to the airport, his family members, or his profession.  His cognitive function is otherwise intact.  A search of his personal belongings reveals an airline ticket from Las Vegas to Arlington, Virginia.  An emergency contact on the patient's phone leads to his wife in Nevada, who reports that her husband "just disappeared" after he found out that his father had passed away that morning.  Physical examination, routine laboratory values, and brain CT scan are unremarkable, and a urine toxicology screen is negative.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Dissociative disorders

Depersonalization/ derealization disorder

  • Persistent or recurrent experiences of 1 or both:
    • Depersonalization (feelings of detachment from, or being an outside observer of, oneself)
    • Derealization (experiencing surroundings as unreal)
  • Intact reality testing

Dissociative amnesia

  • Inability to recall important personal information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature
  • Not explained by another disorder (eg, substance use, posttraumatic stress)

Dissociative identity disorder

  • Marked discontinuity in identity & loss of personal agency with fragmentation into ≥2 distinct personality states
  • Associated with severe trauma/abuse

 

This patient's inability to recall important autobiographical information is suggestive of dissociative amnesia.  It can consist of localized or selective amnesia for a particular event or, as in this patient, more generalized amnesia for personal identity and history.  Onset is typically sudden and preceded by overwhelming or intolerable events.

If the amnesia is associated with traveling or wandering, the term "dissociative fugue" (previously a separate diagnosis in DSM-IV) is used as a specifier for dissociative amnesia in DSM-5.

Definitive diagnosis requires ruling out effects of a substance (alcohol "blackouts," drugs, medications) or a neurological condition.  Dissociative amnesia is not diagnosed if the disturbance is better explained as a symptom of acute or post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) or dissociative identity disorder.

(Choices A and F)  Symptoms of acute stress disorder and PTSD can include dissociative amnesia.  However, symptoms of hyperarousal (eg, hypervigilance, startle response, sleep disturbance), intrusive memories, and avoidance behaviors would be expected.

(Choice B)  Patients with brief psychotic disorder present with delusions, hallucinations, disorganized behavior, or confused speech, none of which this patient displays.  This disorder is often precipitated by a stressor and resolves within a month.

(Choice C)  In depersonalization/derealization disorder, the patient generally has intact autobiographical memory but experiences repeated or chronic feelings of unreality or detachment.

(Choice E)  Although gaps in memory can be experienced in dissociative identity disorder, the diagnosis requires evidence of 2 or more distinct identities that alternate in assuming control of the patient's behavior.  This patient is acutely confused about his identity and shows no evidence of having developed 2 or more distinct personalities.

(Choice G)  Transient global amnesia presents as anterograde amnesia for time and place.  There is no associated loss of personal identity, as in this patient.  The memory loss typically resolves within 24 hours.

Educational objective:
Dissociative amnesia involves isolated impairment in autobiographical memory.  If the amnesia is accompanied by travel or wandering, the specifier of "with dissociative fugue" is given.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Dissociative amnesia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Dissociative disorders in DSM-5.

questionList.questionText: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to depression and suicidal thoughts.  The roommate became alarmed when the patient did not get up for work as usual and reported feeling "so depressed I want to die."  She currently has no suicidal ideation but describes feeling depressed, exhausted, and unable to concentrate.  The patient appears distracted and speaks slowly.  The roommate says, "We were up for the last 3 nights at parties where there was alcohol and other stuff," but reports that her friend was energetic and talkative and appeared to be in a great mood.  However, the patient subsequently slept for 18 hours, had difficulty getting out of bed, and missed work.  She has no medical or psychiatric history but describes brief periods of acute depression over the past several months.  These lasted a few days and were characterized by low energy; hypersomnia; vivid, unpleasant dreams; and increased appetite.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min.  Physical examination is normal.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's acute onset of depression with pronounced fatigue following a period of increased energy is suggestive of cocaine withdrawal.  Individuals often use cocaine in binges, taking the drug repeatedly over a short period to maintain their "high."  Abrupt cessation is typically followed by a "crash," which can include severe depression with suicidal ideation and psychomotor slowing with milder symptoms that resolve within 1-2 weeks.  Cocaine withdrawal involves predominantly psychological features.  Common symptoms include depression, fatigue, hypersomnia, increased dreaming, hyperphagia, impaired concentration, and intense drug craving.  Physical symptoms are minor and rarely require treatment.

(Choices A and F)  This patient's normal physical examination and vital signs make alcohol and opiate withdrawal syndromes unlikely.  Alcohol withdrawal is characterized by CNS hyperactivity, and its symptoms include anxiety, insomnia, tremulousness, tachycardia, and hypertension.  Opiate withdrawal typically presents with dysphoria and is accompanied by myalgia, yawning, and abdominal cramping.  Physical findings include mydriasis, lacrimation, increased bowel sounds, and piloerection.

(Choices B, D, and E)  Primary mood disorders should be diagnosed only when substance-induced causes are ruled out, and they are less likely in this patient given her history of using substances at parties.  In addition, the patient's episode of heightened energy does not meet the duration criteria for either a hypomanic (≥4 days) or manic (≥7 days) episode, and her mood symptoms do not meet the duration criteria for either cyclothymia (≥2 years) or major depressive disorder (≥2 weeks).

Educational objective:
Although physical symptoms are typically minor, cocaine withdrawal can cause acute depression with suicidal ideation.  Other features include fatigue, hypersomnia, increased dreaming, hyperphagia, impaired concentration, and intense drug craving.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Substance induced mood disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Stimulant use disorder
Diagnosis and consequences of cocaine addiction.

questionList.questionText: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the office due to behavioral changes.  The mother says, "We took her to a magic show a few months ago and bought a toy wand from the gift shop.  Now she thinks she has special powers."  The patient brings the wand to school each morning so that "bad things don't happen."  A week ago, she forgot to bring her wand home, and that night, her father was in a motor vehicle collision that resulted in a fractured wrist.  The patient says, "Dad got hurt because of me.  It was my fault."  She has become more protective of the wand and no longer shares it with her classmates because "it will lose its power."  Each night before falling asleep, the patient closes her eyes and taps her wand in the air 3 times to make sure she and her family stay safe.  Vital signs are within normal limits; growth curves are tracking consistently.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This girl's belief that her magic wand can directly influence events around her is characteristic of magical thinking, a normal phase of cognitive development in children age 2-7.  During this phase, children often combine fantasy elements taken from toys and entertainment with real life events.  They can have strong beliefs in the magical powers of objects and the existence of imaginary characters (eg, tooth fairy, fantasy characters, imaginary friends).  This girl's belief that she directly caused her father's injury by forgetting her wand is also an example of the egocentric thinking that characterizes normal cognitive development during these years; young children often see an event as it relates to themselves only and may feel responsible when something bad happens.

This girl should be reassured that her behavior in no way caused her father's accident.  The parents should be reassured that magical thinking is a normal developmental stage that may help children face their fears, resolve conflicts, and develop their imagination and creative thinking.

(Choice A)  Adjustment disorders are characterized by emotional or behavioral disturbances that are out of proportion to precipitating stressors and are functionally impairing.  This child's behavior is age appropriate, and there was no obvious precipitant stressor that preceded her belief in the wand's magic powers.  Her reaction to her father's accident is also consistent with normal cognitive development.

(Choice C)  Pediatric obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by time-consuming repetitive compulsions performed in response to obsessional thoughts.  This girl's bedtime ritual is performed only once and is connected to her age-appropriate magical thinking.  In addition, onset of pediatric OCD is typically in middle, rather than early, childhood.

(Choice D)  Although magical thinking can be seen in patients who go on to develop schizotypal personality disorder, it would typically be accompanied by a persistent pattern of unusual perceptual experiences, eccentric behavior, and excessive social anxiety.  This child's magical thinking is developmentally appropriate and likely to be outgrown.

(Choice E)  Although separation anxiety disorder involves fears of harm to major attachment figures, this patient is attending school without difficulty and does not have excessive distress with separation.

Educational objective:
Young children often engage in magical thinking, involving beliefs in the magical powers of objects and the existence of imaginary characters.  It is a normal phase of cognitive development in children age 2-7.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Child and adolescent mental health

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Cognitive development.

questionList.questionText: A 66-year-old man comes to the office to follow up on his prostate cancer treatment.  The patient has painful, bony metastasis in the pelvis and is being treated with hormonal therapy and radiotherapy.  He has been receiving long-acting and as-needed short-acting morphine, but he continues to have significant pain.  In the past 2 weeks, the patient has also experienced insomnia due to the pain, leading to worsening fatigue.  He has no nausea, constipation, drowsiness, or suicidal ideation.  Urine drug screen is positive for opioids and negative for other substances.  A review of the state prescription drug monitoring program database reveals no irregularities.  In addition to titration of opioid therapy to improve pain control, which of the following responses is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Patients receiving chronic opioid therapy are at risk for opioid overdose, including those with cancer.  In general, patients with prostate cancer and isolated bony metastasis can live for many years; therefore, balancing adequate pain control versus avoiding opioid overdose is crucial.

Because overdose leads to fatal respiratory depression, naloxone, an opioid receptor antagonist, should be offered to every patient receiving chronic opioid therapy, especially those at high risk for overdose; family members should be trained on its use.  Naloxone reverses the effects of opioid toxicity and can be administered intranasally or intramuscularly by bystanders pending arrival of emergency medical services.

Patients at high risk for overdose include those with the following characteristics:

  • Escalating or high-dose opioid therapy, such as this patient
  • Concurrent benzodiazepine use
  • History of substance use disorder or overdose
  • Close contacts (eg, children) who may accidentally ingest the drug

(Choice A)  Calcitonin is often used as adjunctive therapy for patients with painful acute osteoporotic vertebral fracture but is generally not used to treat metastatic bone pain due to lack of evidence regarding its efficacy.

(Choice B)  Concurrent use of a benzodiazepine (eg, clonazepam) with an opioid is highly discouraged due to the increased risk for fatal respiratory depression.  Appropriate pain control might help with insomnia.

(Choice D)  Naltrexone, an opioid antagonist, is used to treat opioid use disorder; it blocks the euphoric effects of opioids and suppresses cravings.  Naltrexone is typically initiated after the patient has stopped taking opioids for 1-2 weeks and is not used with an opioid.

Educational objective:
Opioid overdose causes fatal respiratory depression.  Naloxone should be offered to every patient who receives chronic opioid therapy, especially those at high risk for overdose (eg, high or escalating opioid dosage, concurrent benzodiazepine use).
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Opioids

answerChoiceList.choice: "Bone pain is especially difficult to treat.  Let's try a medication called calcitonin."
"I'll prescribe you clonazepam every night to help with sleep."
"I'll prescribe naloxone in case of overdose and talk to your family about how to use it."
"To prevent addiction, I'll prescribe naltrexone to lessen the euphoria associated with morphine."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Coprescription of opioid and naloxone in office-based practice and emergency department settings in the United States.

questionList.questionText: A 46-year-old hospitalized man is evaluated for confusion.  He was admitted 3 days ago after a motor vehicle collision in which he was a passenger.  He sustained fractures of the right tibia and fibula, which were surgically reduced and fixed.  The patient had a small subdural hematoma without midline shift, which was managed nonoperatively.  He has been receiving intravenous morphine for pain control.  This morning, the patient was agitated and disruptive and was talking to persons who were not there.  He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications.  Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min and regular, and respirations are 22/min.  Pulse oximetry shows 96% on room air.  The patient appears diaphoretic and tremulous and is trying to pull out the intravenous lines.  He is not cooperative for funduscopic examination, but pupils are equal and reactive bilaterally.  Breath sounds are normal and no heart murmurs are heard.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  The surgical incision shows no surrounding erythema.  The patient moves all extremities without limitations.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acute confusion?
questionList.explanationText:
Alcohol withdrawal syndrome

Manifestations

Symptoms/signs

Onset since last
drink (hr)

Mild
withdrawal

Anxiety, insomnia, tremors, diaphoresis, palpitations, gastrointestinal upset, intact orientation

6-24

Seizures

Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic

12-48

Alcoholic
hallucinosis

Visual, auditory, or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs

12-48

Delirium
tremens

Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, hallucinations

48-96

In a patient who has been hospitalized for 72 hours, the onset of acute change in cognition and attention, tachycardia, hypertension, tremulousness, diaphoresis, agitation, and hallucinations should raise suspicion for delirium tremens (DT) due to alcohol withdrawal.

Chronic alcohol use results in insensitivity to GABA, the neurotransmitter principally responsible for maintaining inhibitory tone.  In contrast, a prolonged decrease in or cessation of alcohol intake leads to disequilibrium between inhibition and excitation, favoring excitation of the central, somatic, and autonomic nervous systems.

A history of alcohol consumption may go undetected in patients who have trauma or encephalopathy.  Manifestations of withdrawal may be mistaken for symptoms of the concurrent condition or surgery.  These manifestations vary based on quantity, duration, and time since the last drink and may include:

  • Early withdrawal (6-36 hours) - tremor, anxiety, headache, normal sensorium
  • Neuropsychiatric (12-48 hours) - generalized seizures, hallucinations
  • DT (48-96 hours) - altered sensorium, agitation, tremor, autonomic instability

Management of DT includes ruling out other causes of delirium, providing nutritional and electrolyte supplementation, and administering benzodiazepines.

(Choice B)  Elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with lethargy or obtundation, pupillary abnormalities (eg, enlarged, asymmetric, nonreactive), and Cushing response (eg, hypertension, bradycardia, respiratory depression).  Although this patient has a subdural hematoma, he has normal, reactive pupils and is agitated and tachycardic.

(Choice C)  Fat embolism syndrome occurs 1-3 days following a traumatic injury with the triad of petechiae, pulmonary infiltrates with hypoxia, and altered mentation.  This patient has only altered mentation.

(Choice D)  Malignant hyperthermia is an autosomal dominant disorder of skeletal muscle hypermetabolism that leads to hyperpyrexia, muscle rigidity and breakdown, and respiratory and metabolic acidosis.  It occurs rarely and usually only perioperatively with exposure to volatile anesthetics and/or succinylcholine.

(Choice E)  Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a reaction to neuroleptic medications (eg, haloperidol, fluphenazine) that results in severe ("lead pipe") muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, delirium, and autonomic instability.  This patient is not on neuroleptic medication and does not have a fever.

(Choice F)  Opiate intoxication leads to lethargy, constricted pupils, and respiratory depression.

(Choice G)  Pulmonary embolism is a potential postoperative complication usually presenting with chest pain, dyspnea, hypoxia, tachycardia, and diaphoresis.  Delirium and agitation would be an uncommon presentation, but this patient is not hypoxemic.

Educational objective:
Delirium tremens is a severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal usually presenting 48-96 hours after the last drink.  It is defined by autonomic excitation, agitation, tremor, and altered sensorium.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Alcohol withdrawal

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Management of drug and alcohol withdrawal.

questionList.questionText: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the office by her father due to hyperactivity and impulsivity for the past 4 months.  The father says, "She has so much energy at home and seems to calm down only if she's watching television."  He read a book on discipline but states it did not help him change the patient's behaviors.  The patient is often impatient, takes her siblings' toys without asking, and runs off at the grocery store.  Their house is undergoing a renovation, and despite being told to stay out of the construction zone multiple times, the patient continues to be disobedient.  Her school reported no behavioral concerns at a parent-teacher conference 3 weeks ago, and the patient receives average marks on progress reports.  Vital signs are normal; growth curves are tracking consistently.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  She plays quietly on her father's phone during the visit.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Parent management training

Focus

Parent interventions

Antecedents

(communication
leading to
wanted/unwanted
behaviors)

  • Use (promote wanted behavior):
    • clear instructions
    • calm tones & supportive gestures
    • alternative choices
  • Avoid (promote unwanted behavior):
    • nagging
    • threats
    • harsh comments
    • physical intimidation

Behaviors

(practicing effective
parent-child
interactions)

  • Shaping:
    • small behavioral goals adding to bigger changes
  • Role-play wanted behaviors:
    • artificial situations first
    • build to realistic scenarios

Consequences

(for wanted/
unwanted
behaviors)

  • Reinforce wanted behaviors:
    • praise (verbal, nonverbal)
    • token/point system rewards
  • Manage unwanted behaviors:
    • extinction (eg, ignore, walk away)
    • mild punishment (eg, privilege loss)

Hyperactivity and impulsivity (eg, being overly energetic, running off, taking toys) are nonspecific features that may be due to attention deficit hyperactivity disorder [ADHD]) or another cause (eg, ineffective parenting, personality traits).  When symptoms are frequent, cause impairment, and present across multiple settings (eg, school, home, physician's office), ADHD—for which effective medication management exists (eg, norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors [eg, atomoxetine], stimulants [eg, methylphenidate], alpha-2 adrenergic agonists [eg, clonidine])—should be considered (Choices B and F).

However, when parents describe a child's disobedience as limited to the home setting, problems specific to the parent-child relationship should be suspected.  In this situation, where the father has tried unsuccessfully to manage by using a self-help book, parent management training (PMT) is the treatment of choice and provides an effective intervention for his daughter's inappropriate behaviors (Choice D).

PMT helps parents identify effective parenting methods while redirecting them from ineffective methods.  Sessions usually last 5-10 weeks and seek to identify antecedents (ie, causes) of a child's behaviors and provide a forum for practicing effective behavioral interventions.  Parents are also taught how to provide consistent consequences that promote wanted behaviors (eg, targeted praise, point systems) and decrease unwanted behaviors through extinction (eg, ignoring, walking away) and mild punishment (eg, privilege loss).

(Choice A)  Modifying the patient's screen time should be a part of the overall management strategy because using it to help her "calm down" is rewarding, which reinforces the unwanted behaviors; however, the disobedience is not limited to screen time (eg, runs off at the grocery store, takes siblings' toys), so this alone is not expected to bring the long-term changes needed.

(Choice C)  Lead poisoning can cause behavior and cognitive concerns in children; however, these would be expected to cross multiple settings.  Parent-specific disobedience and average grades suggest ineffective parenting techniques.

Educational objective:
When hyperactivity and impulsivity concerns are limited to the home setting, ineffective parenting methods should be suspected, with parent management training being the treatment of choice.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Child and adolescent mental health

answerChoiceList.choice: Advise the father to discontinue screen time
Provide reassurance that the patient's behaviors are age appropriate

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of "muscle tightness."  The patient reports having stiffness and muscle pain in her neck and shoulders for the past few months.  She was previously a stay-at-home mom but started a new job as a receptionist 6 months ago and spends most of her time seated at a desk.  The patient notes feeling increasingly stressed and fatigued since she started working and cannot get through the day without feeling overwhelmed.  The patient finds herself thinking about "anything but work," including whether her son will get into college and if her husband will get a raise.  She often texts her kids to check-in with them throughout the day and calls at 4 PM to make sure they arrived home safely.  When she gets home in the evenings, she prefers to spend time alone because she tends to get easily irritated by her family.  Medical history is noncontributory.  The patient takes no medications.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Generalized anxiety disorder

Clinical features

  • Excessive, uncontrollable worry (multiple issues) ≥6 months
  • ≥3 of the following symptoms (≥1 in children):
    • Restlessness, feeling on edge
    • Fatigue
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Irritability
    • Muscle tension
    • Sleep disturbance
  • Chronic, fluctuating course; academic/occupational dysfunction

Associated features

  • Physical symptoms related to tension (headaches, neck pain)
  • Comorbid depression, substance use common
  • Increased risk of high health care utilization, cardiovascular events

Treatment

  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • SSRI or SNRI
  • Buspirone

SNRI = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's ≥6-month history of feeling overwhelmed by anxious thoughts (eg, health, family, safety, finances), accompanied by symptoms of muscle tension, irritability, impaired concentration, and fatigue, is consistent with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).  Patients with GAD experience chronic and pervasive anxiety and worry excessively about everyday matters.  They often describe lifelong anxiety but frequently experience worsening symptoms during periods of increased stress, such as this patient's starting a new job.  Symptoms of GAD may also include feeling restless/on edge and sleep disturbance characterized by difficulty falling and staying asleep.

Patients with GAD frequently seek medical attention in the primary care setting for physical symptoms related to muscle tension or for concerns about fatigue or poor sleep.  This patient's neck and shoulder pain is a common presentation.

(Choice A)  In adjustment disorder, emotional and behavioral symptoms develop within 3 months in response to an identifiable stressor and do not meet the criteria for any other mental disorder.  This patient's anxiety has persisted ≥6 months and is consistent with GAD due to her excessive worry about multiple topics and associated physical symptoms.

(Choice C)  There is significant symptom overlap between major depressive disorder and GAD (eg, fatigue, insomnia, impaired concentration).  However, this patient's lack of key depressive symptoms (ie, sadness, decreased interest, anhedonia) and prominent, overwhelming anxiety make GAD the more accurate diagnosis.

(Choice D)  Although this patient is preoccupied with anxious thoughts, she lacks the intrusive, unwanted obsessions and repetitive, ritualistic, compulsive acts required for diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).  Patients with GAD tend to seek reassurance directly (eg, calling home to check on children), whereas compulsive behaviors in OCD are often unrealistically connected to preventing a feared outcome (eg, repeatedly counting to a certain number to prevent illness in a child).

(Choice E)  Anxiety about physical symptoms occurs in both GAD and somatic symptom disorder (SSD).  However, in contrast to SSD, patients with GAD typically have multiple worries about everyday concerns and are not exclusively focused on medically unexplained symptoms.

Educational objective:
Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by overwhelming and pervasive anxiety lasting ≥6 months.  Associated symptoms include restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, and sleep disturbance.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Generalized anxiety disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Generalized anxiety disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 60-year-old physician is admitted to the hospital for jaundice and weight loss.  His medical history is noncontributory.  After a detailed workup, advanced pancreatic carcinoma is diagnosed.  Although the patient is advised to slow down and spend more time with his family, he insists on continuing to work, saying, "It's a good distraction to think about other people's medical problems."  Each day after work, he spends several hours reviewing and analyzing his own diagnostic tests and researching experimental chemotherapy regimens for pancreatic cancer.  The patient's family members wish he would take time off to rest, but he insists that would make him feel worse.  Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is the best explanation for this patient's behavior?
questionList.explanationText:
Key defense mechanisms

Immature

  • Acting out: Expressing unacceptable feelings through actions
  • Denial: Behaving as if an aspect of reality does not exist
  • Displacement: Transferring feelings to less threatening object/person
  • Intellectualization: Focusing on nonemotional aspects to avoid distressing feelings
  • Passive aggression: Avoiding conflict by expressing hostility covertly
  • Projection: Attributing one’s own feelings to others
  • Rationalization: Justifying behavior to avoid difficult truths
  • Reaction formation: Transforming unacceptable feelings/impulses into the opposite
  • Regression: Reverting to earlier developmental stage
  • Splitting: Experiencing a person/situation as either all positive or all negative

Mature

  • Sublimation: Channeling impulses into socially acceptable behaviors
  • Suppression: Putting unwanted feelings aside to cope with reality

Psychological defense mechanisms are unconscious means of responding and adapting to emotional stressors that serve to decrease anxiety and provide a sense of security or control.  This patient is primarily employing intellectualization, a defense mechanism that allows him to avoid anxiety by focusing on the nonemotional aspects of his cancer diagnosis.

His decision to keep working serves as an intellectual focus as he spends hours a day analyzing test results and researching experimental therapies rather than confronting the painful emotions associated with his poor prognosis.  His overreliance on intellectualization interferes with his ability to deal with his feelings and grieve with his family.

(Choice A)  Altruism involves managing unpleasant emotions through unselfish devotion or service to others.  This patient's decision to keep working is primarily motivated by his need for an intellectual distraction from his own problems rather than a desire to help others.

(Choice B)  Denial is the failure to accept a disturbing aspect of external reality (eg, if this patient refused to acknowledge his diagnosis and insisted that nothing was wrong in the face of all evidence to the contrary).

(Choice C)  Displacement is the transfer of feelings or impulses toward a safer, more acceptable person or situation (eg, if this physician displaced his anxiety by becoming excessively worried about his patients instead of his own condition).

(Choice E)  Rationalization involves attempting to justify or excuse a behavior or decision rather than acknowledging the true motives, significance, or consequences of it.  For example, this would occur if the physician rationalized his decision to keep working by saying he was unable to transfer his patients to another caregiver when this was not the case.

(Choice F)  Reaction formation involves transforming an unacceptable feeling or impulse into its extreme opposite (eg, if this patient feared dying but behaved in an overly optimistic and fearless manner about his treatment and prognosis).

Educational objective:
Intellectualization is the transformation of a distressing event into a situation devoid of emotion to avoid confrontation of uncomfortable emotional components.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Defense mechanisms

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Understanding defense mechanisms.

questionList.questionText: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by coworkers due to agitated behavior.  She is alert but appears distracted by unseen stimuli.  During triage, the patient yells at a nurse for being "too close" to her; she also attempts to lift an equipment cart and throws the blood pressure cuff across the room.  The patient provides nonsensical responses when asked about her medical history.  Her coworkers say that she has depression and anxiety but do not know what medications she takes.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, pulse is 126/min, and respirations are 18/min.  Physical examination shows equal and reactive pupils, intact extraocular movements, and nystagmus.  Mild rigidity is noted and is most prominent in the upper extremities.  Upper and lower limb deep tendon reflexes are 2+.  No tremors are observed, and gait is ataxic.  The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has signs and symptoms of phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication, including:

  • Disorientation with severe agitation
  • Aggression with delusions of enhanced strength
  • Psychosis (eg, paranoia, hallucinations)
  • Tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia
  • Nystagmus and ataxia

PCP is a dissociative drug of abuse that has anesthetic and analgesic properties.  It acts on NMDA receptors (excitatory and psychotic effects), dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin receptors (adrenergic and dopaminergic effects), and the sigma receptor complex (psychotic and anticholinergic effects).  In many cases, PCP use can lead to psychotic and violent behavior, diminished pain perception, and subsequent physical injuries.

The onset of action is rapid, and the duration of action is generally <8 hours.  High doses can cause severe hypertension, seizures, rigidity, and life-threatening hyperthermia.  PCP intoxication is treated with both supportive therapy and benzodiazepines.

(Choice A)  Severe alcohol withdrawal (ie, delirium tremens) can present with confusion and hallucinations, agitation, and hemodynamic instability (eg, tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia).  Nystagmus can be present in cases with associated cerebellar degeneration.  However, alcohol withdrawal typically follows stepwise worsening of symptoms from mild withdrawal, seizures, alcoholic hallucinosis, and then to delirium tremens.  In addition, tremors (absent in this patient) are a hallmark of alcohol withdrawal.

(Choice B)  Cerebellar stroke can present with nystagmus and ataxia but does not cause agitation, aggression, or psychosis.

(Choice C)  Methamphetamine intoxication can also cause severe psychomotor agitation, hallucinations, tachycardia, and hypertension, but nystagmus is less common.  Methamphetamine intoxication may last up to 20 hours (longer than PCP intoxication).

(Choice D)  Multiple sclerosis can present with nystagmus and ataxia and sometimes behavior changes (eg, inappropriate laughing), but it does not cause severe aggression or hemodynamic changes.

(Choice F)  Serotonin syndrome is characterized by mental status changes, autonomic dysregulation, and neuromuscular hyperactivity, features seen in this patient.  However, the aggression with delusions of enhanced strength, nystagmus, and ataxia are more consistent with PCP intoxication.

Educational objective:
Phencyclidine is a dissociative anesthetic that characteristically causes nystagmus.  It can also cause dissociative feelings, psychotic and violent behavior, severe hypertension, and hyperthermia.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Phencyclidine

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Phencyclidine intoxication case series study.

questionList.questionText: During bedside rounds, a senior resident is reprimanded by the chief of service for mismanaging the care of a private patient.  Although the resident, believing that she made the right decision, is angry about the attending's assessment, she says nothing.  Later that day, she is teaching a group of medical students and asks one of them to list the differential diagnosis of hematuria.  After a student lists several diagnostic possibilities but neglects to mention nephrolithiasis, the resident walks out of the room, saying, "Why do I bother to assign readings if none of you take them seriously?"  The student is upset by this comment and speaks to the resident later in the day, saying, "I am open to feedback on my performance but would hope that you would not belittle me in public."  Which of the following defense mechanisms is exhibited by the resident's behavior toward the student?
questionList.explanationText:
Key defense mechanisms

Immature

  • Acting out: expressing unacceptable feelings through actions
  • Denial: behaving as if an aspect of reality does not exist
  • Displacement: transferring feelings to less threatening object/person
  • Intellectualization: focusing on nonemotional aspects to avoid distressing feelings
  • Passive aggression: avoiding conflict by expressing hostility covertly
  • Projection: attributing one's own feelings to others
  • Rationalization: justifying behavior to avoid difficult truths
  • Reaction formation: transforming unacceptable feelings/impulses into the opposite
  • Regression: reverting to earlier developmental stage
  • Splitting: experiencing a person/situation as either all positive or all negative

Mature

  • Sublimation: channeling impulses into socially acceptable behaviors
  • Suppression: putting unwanted feelings aside to cope with reality

Psychological defense mechanisms are unconscious means of responding and adapting to different situations while preserving self-image.  These mechanisms serve to decrease anxiety associated with shame and vulnerability and ensure a feeling of safety in the face of disappointments.  Immature defense mechanisms are commonly seen in children or in adults during times of stress.  They provide short-term relief but often result in long-term complications, such as interpersonal difficulties and misunderstandings.  Mature defense mechanisms represent a more constructive way to approach reality.

Displacement is an immature defense mechanism that involves transferring emotions associated with an upsetting object or person to a safer, alternate object or person.  This resident likely was shamed and angered by being reprimanded by the chief of service.  Instead of acknowledging her feelings, she displaces her anger onto a safer target by making shaming comments to the students she is teaching.

(Choice A)  Acting out involves expressing unacceptable feelings through impulsive physical actions (eg, if the resident pounded the desk or destroyed items in the attending's office in response to being criticized).

(Choice C)  In passive aggression, emotions are expressed in a roundabout way instead of directly (eg, if the resident "forgot" about rounds the next day, leaving the attending to manage patients alone).

(Choice D)  Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable feelings to someone else (eg, if the resident, unconsciously harboring anger toward the attending, instead accuses the student of behaving angrily).

(Choice E)  In regression, people revert to an earlier pattern of behavior or coping, as if they were much younger (eg, if the resident had a temper tantrum in front of the chief of service when he berated her).

(Choice F)  In splitting, people experience a situation as either all positive or all negative (eg, if the resident alternately idealized and then devalued the chief of service, first believing him to be "the best attending in the world" and then "the worst").

Educational objective:
Displacement is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual displaces negative feelings associated with a person or situation onto a safer object or situation.

questionList.title: Defense mechanisms

questionList.questionText: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to difficulties at school.  The patient was adopted at age 2 from an orphanage.  Medical history is significant for a heart murmur that resolved when he was an infant.  His mother says, "His handwriting is illegible and the school wants to keep him back a grade.  He has always struggled to sit still and focus; he is clumsy and breaks things without meaning to.  He gets upset easily and throws things or hits his brothers when they don't do what he wants."  The patient's teacher has reported that he doesn't listen, talks back, and distracts other children.  Psychoeducational testing revealed an IQ score of 85.  In the office, the boy is playing with a toy.  When his mother takes it away, he hits her, starts crying, and becomes difficult to console.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Weight and height are tracking at the 30th percentile, but head circumference is below the 10th percentile.  Physical examination shows a thin upper lip and short palpebral fissures.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's behavioral difficulties (distractibility, emotional reactivity), growth retardation, and facial anomalies are suggestive of fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS).  Features of FAS include facial dysmorphism (short palpebral fissures, thin upper lip, smooth philtrum), growth retardation, and CNS involvement, which manifests in structural and/or neurobehavioral difficulties.  Other systems that may be affected include the heart, skeletal, renal, ocular, and auditory systems.

Intrauterine alcohol exposure negatively impacts the fetal brain via inhibition of NMDA and hyperactivation of GABA receptors.  Deficits in development of the corpus callosum, cerebellum, and basal ganglia result in abnormal reflexes, tone, and coordination, manifesting in this patient as difficulty with writing and clumsiness.  A decrease in the volume of the frontal lobe and dysfunction of the amygdala result in deficits in executive functioning, impulse control, and emotion regulation.  Features of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) are common (Choice A).  Other neurobehavioral manifestations include cognitive impairment, seizures, learning disabilities, and social skill deficits.

(Choices B and H)  DiGeorge syndrome (DGS) and velocardiofacial syndrome (VCFS) are associated with a deletion of chromosome 22q11 affecting pharyngeal pouch development.  DGS presents with abnormal conotruncal cardiac development, a hypoplastic thymus, and hypocalcemia.  It is associated with developmental delay and social and emotional skill deficits.  VCFS presents with an elongated face, retrognathia, a prominent nose, hypernasal speech, and cardiac defects.  Learning disabilities, schizophrenia, and paranoia may be present.

(Choice C)  Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is associated with epicanthal folds, upslanting palpebral fissures, flat nasal bridge, protruding tongue, and varying degrees of intellectual disability.

(Choice E)  Fragile X syndrome is the most common form of inherited intellectual disability.  It is associated with unstable CGG (cytosine-guanine-guanine) trinucleotide repeats on the X chromosome.  Features include intellectual disability; a long, narrow face; large, protruding ears; macrocephaly; and macroorchidism.  ADHD and autistic features are common.

(Choices F and G)  Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of defiant behavior, vindictiveness, and an angry or irritable mood.  Reactive attachment disorder presents with lack of positive affect, social and emotional withdrawal, and poor response to comfort.  Neither of these conditions would explain facial anomalies or incoordination.

Educational objective:
Neurobehavioral manifestations of fetal alcohol syndrome include intellectual disability, emotional dysregulation, inattention, and social skill deficits.  Accompanying features include facial dysmorphism (short palpebral fissures, thin upper lip, smooth philtrum) and growth retardation.

questionList.questionText: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police officers after being found naked and yelling in the street.  The patient was walking up to cars stopped at a traffic signal, cursing at drivers, and banging on windows.  He has been admitted to the hospital several times due to agitation resulting from substance use.  Medical history includes depression.  The patient is highly agitated; attempts to elicit a history are unsuccessful.  He repeatedly says, "They are all out to get me.  They are coming through the walls, ready to kill me."  The patient alternates between screaming and pounding on the walls.  Temperature is 38.3 C (100.9 F), blood pressure is 148/100 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 16/min.  Physical examination shows ataxia, nystagmus, and muscle rigidity.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Management of substance-induced emergencies

Class

Acute clinical features

Management

PCP
(phencyclidine)

  • Violent behavior
  • Dissociation
  • Hallucinations
  • Amnesia
  • Nystagmus (horizontal or vertical)
  • Ataxia
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Antipsychotics

Cocaine

  • Euphoria
  • Agitation/psychosis
  • Chest pain
  • Seizures
  • Tachycardia/hypertension
  • Mydriasis
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Antipsychotics

Methamphetamine

  • Violent behavior
  • Psychosis/diaphoresis
  • Tachycardia/hypertension
  • Choreiform movements
  • Tooth decay
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Antipsychotics

Alcohol

  • Aggression
  • Confusion/disorientation
  • Depressed mental status
  • Respiratory depression
  • Antipsychotics

Opioids

  • Euphoria
  • Depressed mental status
  • Miosis
  • Respiratory depression
  • Constipation
  • Naloxone

This patient's presentation suggests phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication.  PCP acts on the following:

  • NMDA receptors, particularly in the hippocampus and limbic system (causing excitatory and psychotic effects)

  • Dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin receptors (causing adrenergic and dopaminergic effects)

  • The sigma receptor complex (causing psychotic and anticholinergic effects)

Therefore, PCP intoxication commonly presents with severe agitation, delusions of enhanced strength, psychosis (eg, paranoia, hallucinations), analgesia, and aggression.  Physical examination findings include multidirectional nystagmus (horizontal, vertical, and/or rotary), hypertension, tachycardia, and disorientation.  Severe cases may present with hyperthermia, ataxia, muscle rigidity, seizures, and coma.

The treatment of PCP intoxication involves supportive management and control of agitation and aggression to maintain safety.  Benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam, midazolam) are the preferred agents for managing PCP-associated agitation; lorazepam has a rapid onset of action, which allows for faster management of behavioral crises.  In addition, the sedation achieved with benzodiazepines can help manage complications (eg, hyperthermia, hypertension) and protect against seizures.  If there is an incomplete response to benzodiazepines, antipsychotics can be used as adjunctive treatment.

(Choice A)  Cyproheptadine is a serotonin antagonist that can be used in the management of serotonin syndrome.  Muscular rigidity, delirium, hyperthermia, and abnormal eye movements are signs of serotonin syndrome; however, this patient's history of repeated hospitalizations due to substance use and significant aggression (ie, screaming, pounding on walls) make PCP intoxication more likely.

(Choice B)  Dexmedetomidine is an agonist at the alpha-2 receptor that is commonly used in the intensive care unit and for procedural sedation.  It is not typically used in the treatment of PCP intoxication.

(Choice D)  Phentolamine is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that may be used in specific cases of hypertensive emergencies (eg, pheochromocytoma).

(Choice E)  Urinary acidification, which increases PCP clearance, is no longer recommended as a treatment for PCP intoxication because it is largely ineffective—it increases clearance by only 1%—and increases the risk for acidosis and renal damage.

Educational objective:
Phencyclidine intoxication presents with severe agitation, delusions of enhanced strength, psychosis, analgesia, multidirectional nystagmus, hypertension, tachycardia, and disorientation.  Agitation and aggression can be managed with benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam).
